With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swords Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
• The classic Swords Dance sweeper is still a big threat, thanks to its good bulk, unique Speed tier, and excellent use of Terastallization.

  • Outrage versus Dragon Claw: Outrage is by far Garchomp's strongest STAB move, but the lock-in effect makes it very vulnerable to Fairy-types such as Mimikyu.

  • Fire Fang versus Tera Blast: Despite its low base power, Fire Fang is Garchomp's best shot at breaking past Corviknight after a Swords Dance. If Garchomp is almost always Terastallized on your team, Tera Blast can be used instead.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has excellent synergy with Garchomp's typing, letting it more effectively tackle faster Dragon-types, Iron Bundle, Mimikyu, and Ice Shard from the likes of Baxcalibur and Cloyster.

  • Fairy: Fairy is an even stronger option against Dragon-types, and gives Garchomp a better matchup against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: While the Stealth Rock weakness is unfortunate against bulkier teams, a Fire Tera type lets Life Orb Garchomp OHKO Corviknight with a +2 Fire Fang 93.8% of the time.

  • Ground: While the defensive synergy with Garchomp's former typing isn't that strong, a Ground Tera type lets Garchomp become more of a hit-and-run attacker with Earthquake, dealing good damage to Dondozo before being forced out by Yawn.

Items

  • Life Orb: This is the best option for damage output.

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Garchomp deal with major status users more easily, such as Dragapult and Breloom.

  • Mirror Herb: Mirror Herb gives Garchomp the potential to severely punish set-up sweepers such as Dragapult and Dragonite, with the right Tera type.

  • Focus Sash: Surviving shocking attacks with Focus Sash gives Garchomp new sweeping and revenge killing potential.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description:
• While Garchomp is known for its offensive prowess, it can also support its teammates with entry hazards and phazing.

  • Earthquake versus Bulldoze: Bulldoze brings utility against Choice Scarf and naturally fast grounded opponents, but its lower Base Power makes Garchomp more passive against bulkier Pokemon.

  • Dragon Tail: Dragon Tail has marvelous synergy with setting up hazards, making it the prime choice for a Dragon-type STAB despite the lowered priority.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: If using Tera Fairy, this can help Garchomp muscle past Great Tusk, a foe that can threaten to Rapid Spin your hazards away.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: Fairy Tera type provides Garchomp with an immunity to Dragon-type attacks, and is a big help against Great Tusk.

  • Steel: Terastallizing into a Steel-type makes Garchomp resist Dragon-, Ice- and Fairy-type attacks, making it a safer lead against opposing Dragon-type leads and Iron Bundle, at the cost of being vulnerable to Tera Fire Dragons and Fighting- and Ground-types.

EV spreads

  • 188 HP / 236 Def / 84 Spe with Impish: This EV spread lets Garchomp survive Adamant Dragonite's Outrage while also outspeeding it.

  • 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe with Jolly: While this spread doesn't take physical hits as well, it lets Garchomp outspeed Gholdengo, Baxcalibur, Great Tusk, and Rotom-W.

Items

  • Sitrus Berry: This prevents Choice Band Dragapult from OHKOing Garchomp, as it activates after the first hit, and the HP recovered doesn't allow the second one to get the KO, unless Dragapult is Terastallized into a Dragon-type.

  • Rocky Helmet: Combined with Rough Skin, Rocky Helmet severely punishes contact moves.

  • Red Card: With Red Card, Garchomp will be able to phaze foes Terastallizing into a Fairy type once.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Garchomp's fantastic Speed tier and power make it a fine Choice item user, especially when it can catch its softer checks off guard, such as Dragapult and Corviknight.

  • Stone Edge versus Rock Tomb: Stone Edge deals massive damage to common Tera Flying Pokemon such as Gholdengo, and it prevents it from being walled by Tera Fairy Rotom-W. Rock Tomb is fairly weak, but the speed control can be very useful on Choice Scarf variants if sacrificing Garchomp.

  • Iron Head: With Tera Steel, Iron Head lets Garchomp beat Tera Fairy Levitate foes such as Rotom-W.

Other Options

  • Crunch: Crunch lets Garchomp deal massive damage to Air Balloon Gholdengo, though it doesn't cover much else.

  • Fire Fang While weak, this is Garchomp's best option against Corviknight when not Tera Fire.

Tera Types

  • Fire: When combined with Tera Blast, Tera Fire lets even Choice Scarf Garchomp possibly 2HKO Corviknight. The Fairy and Ice resistance is also very helpful.

  • Steel: Tera Steel is a good defensive alternative to Fire, retaining the useful Stealth Rock resistance and preforming better against Dragon- and Fairy-types.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy goes all in on the Dragon-type immunity, and deals with Great Tusk and Flutter Mane better than other Tera types.

  • Ground: The incredible power boost Earthquake gets from Tera Ground is worth considering, with Choice Band possibly 2HKOing physically defensive Dondozo with it.

Items

  • Choice Band: Choice Band trades revenge killing for wallbreaking, letting Garchomp reliably 2HKO Skeledirge and deal massive damage to Corviknight with Fire-type Tera Blast.

  • Choice Scarf: With Choice Scarf, Garchomp is able to outspeed and revenge kill key threats, such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Choice Specs Iron Moth, making it a potent late-game cleaner as well.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description: With good natural bulk, a great typing, phazing, and both Spikes and Stealth Rock, Garchomp is an effective entry hazard setter that also checks common threats like Orichalcum Pulse Ceruledge. Swords Dance is an option over either entry hazard to pressure bulkier teams. Dragon Tail forces switches and potentially create a favorable situation for Garchomp and helps rack up even more entry hazard damage. As Garchomp does not have any reliable recovery, Leftovers is the preferred option to give Garchomp longevity, but Heavy-Duty Boots is great for opposing hazard-stack matchups. Due to Garchomp mainly being an entry hazard setter, it greatly appreciates teammates such as Good as Gold Skeledirge to keep the entry hazards up in the face of Defog and Rapid Spin. Garchomp also works well with offensive threats such as Sheer Force Gengar, as the entry hazards can wear down its checks into KO range. Garchomp struggles to check common attackers like Noivern and Greninja, so secondary checks like physically defensive Clodsire are appreciated.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Inner Focus prevents Lucario from having its Attack dropped by Salamence's Intimidate, but Justified is an option to gain value from Knock Off when switching into Grafaiai for setup opportunities. Tera Normal lets Lucario gain a STAB bonus on its Extreme Speed to sweep teams after setting up.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature retains enough Attack for Hippowdon to OHKO Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum before investing remaining EVs in HP and Special Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Few Pokemon are more reliable at setting up Stealth Rock and phazing than Hippowdon.

  • Whirlwind: This is a more direct phazing option than Yawn, and it is helpful against dangerous setup sweepers that may run Lum Berry, such as Dragonite and Garchomp.

  • Slack Off: Slack Off may seem like an obvious choice to make a defensive Pokemon last longer, but Hippowdon is often more focused on support than walling, so Slack Off doesn't fit every team.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb not only provides helpful speed control, but also pops Air Balloon on foes Hippowdon would otherwise struggle with, such as Gholdengo.

Other Options

  • Fissure: Hippowdon isn't quite as good at using Fissure as Dondozo and Garganacl, and it can be difficult to fit in, but it does severely punish passive play.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Hippowdon doesn't Terastallize often, but a Grass Tera type does help it against Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Water-types such as Rotom-W.

  • Steel: Tera Steel allows specially defensive Hippowdon to avoid a 2HKO from Iron Bundle that lack Choice Specs.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD with Careful: Patching up Hippowdon's weaker Special Defense is quite useful against special attackers, such as having a 6.3% chance of surviving Gholdengo's +2 Make It Rain, and Choice Specs Hydreigon no longer being able to 2HKO Sitrus Berry Hippowdon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Impish: A physically defensive spread means not even Choice Band Tera Dragon Dragapult will be able to 2HKO Sitrus Berry Hippowdon.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fluffy Hippowdon is a remarkable physical wall thanks to its defensive stats, reliable recovery in Slack Off, and pure Ground typing, letting it check non-Mold Breaker offensive threats like Dragonite, Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing. Whirlwind prevents foes like the aforementioned Dragonite from setting up. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it checks and lets it pseudo-spinblock Great Tusk, Cyclizar, and Iron Treads; alternatively, Leftovers gives it extra recovery without having to waste Slack Off PP. 25 Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight, allowing it to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Specially defensive walls like Corviknight, Florges, and Blissey can compensate for Hippowdon's poor Special Defense and check foes like Chi-Yu and Greninja. In return, they appreciate Hippowdon dealing with Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Fighting)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

vgc2023.overview:
• Snow lets Abomasnow carve itself a niche in the current metagame.

  • Abomasnow is a decent offensive support Pokemon with Aurora Veil, which partners well with various Ice-types such as Baxcalibur, Cetitan, and Glaceon, as they gain a Defense boost in snow.

  • Abomasnow's offensive typing is well-suited in a metagame filled with Ground-, Dragon-, and Water-types such as Garchomp, Hydreigon, and Rotom-W.

  • Despite the Defense boost in snow, Abomasnow is still fairly specially frail with a poor set of weaknesses that leave it vulnerable to some of the most common special attackers in the format like Gholdengo and Armarouge.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Giga Drain gives Abomasnow some longevity when behind Aurora Veil and lets it beat the likes of Rotom-W and Palafin which resist Blizzard. Earth Power is an alternative that hits Fire- and Steel-types like Torkoal and Gholdengo, notably OHKOing the former when Terastallized.

  • Abomansow runs items that help it overcome its crucial weaknesses. Focus Sash allows it to take any one hit, such as Rotom-H's Overheat, letting it set up Aurora Veil. Babiri Berry serves a similar purpose, allowing it to survive Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Tera Steel Hydreigon's Flash Cannon.

  • The Speed investment allows Abomsnow to outspeed Garchomp while in Tailwind.

  • Water is the primary Tera type used by Abomasnow, turning its Fire and Steel weaknesses into resistances. Ground is an alternative Tera type that allows it to fire off STAB-boosted Earth Powers, catching its common checks by surprise.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Electric)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• In a metagame with very few special attackers, Magnezone carves a strong niche as an Electric-type attacker that can take out the common physical walls, such as Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Magnezone’s STAB combination is difficult to switch into, especially with Choice Specs. Clodsire, the most noteworthy special wall in the format, can fall to an Analytic-boosted Flash Cannon or Steel Beam when carrying Choice Specs.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy-type Tera Blast is very useful against common Dragon-types, most notably Garchomp and Roaring Moon.

  • Fighting: Gaining a resistance to Dark allows Magnezone to surprise and defeat Kingambit, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon.

  • Grass: Grass has excellent defensive and offense synergy with Magnezone, especially through its utility against Ground-type attackers and Spore immunity. Most notably, Tera Blast Grass can OHKO max SpD Hippowdon with Choice Specs.

  • Flying: Flying has wonderful defensive synergy with Magnezone, reversing its Ground and Fighting weaknesses, and lets Tera Blast hit Grass-types harder.

  • Water: Offensively, Water serves a similar role to Grass, letting Tera Blast nail Ground-types. Water lacks a Ground resistance or a Spore immunity, but it gives Magnezone a much-appreciated Fire resistance for Pokemon like Skeledirge. Much like in the case of Grass, Tera Blast Water can OHKO Hippowdon, while also having the possibility of KOing Unaware Clodsire, although the risk it runs when considering Water Absorb should be noted.

  • Steel: The boost from Tera Steel makes Steel Beam absurdly powerful, with Analytic letting Choice Specs Magnezone OHKO even offensive Multiscale Dragonite!

EV Spreads

  • 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Modest: Running at least some Speed investment lets Magnezone outspeed critical Pokemon like Azumarill, Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Kingambit. 252 EVs give Magnezone a chance at outspeeding slow Mimikyu, Dragonite, Gholdengo, and Annihilape.

  • 188 HP / 252 SpA / 60 Spe with Modest: Magnezone's excellent typing means you often switch it into attacks, especially if you aren’t using Sturdy as an ability. This spread sacrifices some of Magnezone's Speed to raise its capabilities as a pivot. However, reducing the Speed EVs below 60 is not recommended, as it is the minimum required line to outspeed an uninvested Corviknight.

Items

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs gives Magnezone a devastating amount of power, with even Clodsire having trouble handling it.

  • Assault Vest: The increase in special bulk helps Magnezone against the myriad of choice item special attacking Dragon-types, like Hydreigon and Dragapult.

Abilities

  • Analytic: A Magnezone boosted by both Choice Specs and Analytic is incredibly hard to switch into, making it easier for Magnezone to generate momentum.

  • Sturdy: With Sturdy's guaranteed survivability and Magnezone's high damage output, Magnezone will very likely take down at least one Pokemon per game. Sturdy also helps Magnezone play around Dondozo, as it can safely come in on Fissure and use Volt Switch against it, which renders Yawn moot. However, if Magnezone switches into a Yawn and not Fissure, it should be noted that Dondozo often runs Protect to block Volt Switch and ensure Magnezone falls asleep.

  • Magnet Pull: Magnet Pull ensures Magnezone can eliminate Corviknight. In the case Magnezone uses Fighting as its Tera Type, Magnet Pull also allows it to beat both Kingambit and Tera Steel Hydreigon with more reliability.

sets.name: Defensive

sets.name: Choice Attacker
sets.description:
• Rotom-H sets itself apart from other Fire-types, with its Ground immunity and Volt Switch pivoting.

  • Trick: Trick gives Rotom-H an excellent tool against defensive foes, such as Dondozo and Skeledirge.

  • Using a neutral nature with a Timid mint: Make sure to get a Rotom-H with a neutral nature and then use a Timid Mint on it. This way, it can't be confused by any Berries given with Trick.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera typing with Tera Blast makes Rotom-H much better equipped to handle normally problematic Dragon-types, such as Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Dragapult.

  • Electric: Electric is an easy Tera type to recommend, as it increases damage output and removes all of Rotom-H's weaknesses.

  • Fire: When paired with Tera Blast, Rotom-H now has a much more reliable Fire-type STAB move than Overheat, at the cost of retaining several problematic weaknesses.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-H outspeed normally problematic threats such as Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Specs: The extra power makes Rotom-H far more difficult to wall, with defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Thunderbolt.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Rotom-W's Speed, which notably allows it to outpace Gholdengo, access to Volt Switch, and great typing make it an excellent pivot and revenge killer.

  • Trick: If using a Choice Item, Trick is seriously worth considering for its ability to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo. Make sure Rotom-W is a neutral nature that has had a Timid Mint used on it. This way, Rotom-W can eat any Berry without getting confused.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: When combined with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type lets Rotom-W take on Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon far more effectively.

  • Electric: Not only does the damage boost from Tera Electric come in handy, but it also removes any weaknesses Rotom-W has.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf lets Rotom-W outspeed major threats such as Dragapult and Meowscarada.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs tends to be safer to Trick than Choice Scarf, and it gives a big power boost.

  • Assault Vest: Increasing Rotom-W's special bulk gives it a far better matchup against foes like Flutter Mane and Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Rotom-W's Special Attack is part of what makes it an effective revenge killer if using a Choice Item.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: This spread sacrifices Rotom-W's revenge killing potential, but, in exchange, it makes it a better pivot, and the better bulk makes Rotom-W more suited to finding the right time to cripple a wall with Trick. It's also is the best spread to use on Assault Vest sets.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• With a great typing, ability, and good bulk, Rotom-W makes for an effective user of Nasty Plot.

  • Fairy Tera Blast: This move is essential for getting past Dragon-types like Dragapult and Roaring Moon. Even when not Terastallized, it's a decent coverage move.

  • Hydro Pump versus Substitute: Hydro Pump is by far Rotom-W's strongest STAB, but it can be worth sacrificing for Substitute, which lets Rotom-W effectively defeat most Garganacl and defensive Dondozo.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Rotom-W can turn the tables on its Dragon-type adversaries.

Items

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Rotom-W easily set up on Hippowdon, and avoid getting put to sleep by Dondozo.

  • Sitrus Berry: If Sleep isn't a big issue, Rotom-W appreciates the burst recovery Sitrus Berry provides.

  • Covert Cloak: If using Hydro Pump, this is Rotom-W's best way around Garganacl.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: Maximizing Speed with a Timid nature gives Rotom-W the jump on Gholdengo. If Gholdengo isn't an issue, a Modest nature will still outspeed Jolly Breloom.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Modest: Rotom-W's good bulk can be maximized instead of outspeeding Breloom; this spread avoids the 2HKO from Timid Gholdengo's Shadow Ball.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This set will be up for reservation once the analysis process for Series 2 begins.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Tera Fairy allows Rotom-C to resist First Impression from Lokix and Slither Wing aiming to revenge kill it. Tera Fairy also helps Rotom-C take attacks like Close Combat from Lucario and cripple it with Will-O-Wisp.

Tera Steel also prevents Rotom-C from being revenge killed by Lokix and Slither Wing while gaining a Toxic immunity, allowing it to switch into Quagsire without fear.

vgc2023.overview:
• Lilligant exists purely to facilitate Torkoal, providing excellent support with its blistering speed thanks to Chlorophyll. After You allows Torkoal to outspeed foes and hit incredibly hard with Eruption. Sleep Powder can disable a Pokemon that would otherwise threaten Torkoal or stop a sweep. Garchomp, notably, is vulnerable to sleep and is heavily damaged by Leaf Storm. Dondozo is similarly 2HKOed if it doesn't run Assault Vest, even after a Commander boost, and also susceptible to sleep.

  • As Torkoal excels on Trick Room teams, Lilligant will often end up teaming with Trick Room Pokemon. Indeedee's Psychic Terrain and Farigiraf's Armor Tail protect Lilligant from priority moves such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed, and both appreciate Lilligant's ability to disable Dark-type Pokemon such as Kingambit with Sleep Powder. After You lets Guts Hariyama turn the tables on faster Pokemon, and it protects Lilligant in return with Wide Guard and Fake Out. Annihilape appreciates Sleep Powder giving it free turns to use Bulk Up so it can sweep.

  • Talonflame and Murkrow can preempt Lilligant despite Chlorophyll with priority Tailwind, Taunt, and Quash. Similarly, Lilligant hates it when other weather setters hit the field due to its sudden drop in Speed.

sets.name: Chlorophyll Support
sets.description:
• Leaf Storm is Lilligant's strongest STAB option and gives it some offensive presence, notably checking Water- and Ground-types. Sleep Powder shuts down Pokemon that would otherwise threaten Lilligant or its partner and can punish switch-ins. After You is a phenomenal speed control tool that, with Lilligant's fantastic Speed via Chlorophyll, sets the stage for moves like Torkoal's Eruption.

  • Focus Sash is all but mandatory for Lilligant to function due to its frailty. Wide Lens is an option to shore up Sleep Powder's and Leaf Storm's consistency, but it leaves Lilligant vulnerable to OHKOs from most strong attackers.

  • Timid Lilligant is usually superior due to it outrunning Pokemon like Timid Gholdengo in Tailwind. Modest Lilligant can nab potential OHKOs on the likes of Maushold, bulky Rotom-W, and Tera Ground Garchomp, however, while having a very high chance of 2HKOing Garchomp before Terastallization.

  • Lilligant will rarely Terastallize but still has decent options. Tera Water lets it survive a Fire-type attack without giving it too many weaknesses. Tera Flying allows it to pair with an Earthquake user and continue to provide support. Tera Blast with Tera Ground covers Steel- and Fire-types such as Armarouge, Ceruledge, and Gholdengo but is generally not worth it.

  • Helping Hand gives Lilligant a good priority move to use in Trick Room, boosting Torkoal's spread damage to staggering levels. Quiver Dance allows Lilligant to maintain speed control outside of sun and gives its offense more bite. Energy Ball gives Lilligant a more consistent attack than Leaf Storm and is the attack of choice with Quiver Dance, but its unboosted damage leaves a lot to be desired. Any set using Quiver Dance or Energy Ball should run a Modest nature.

sets.name: Redirection Support
sets.description:
• This EV spread and nature allow Amoonguss to survive two consecutive Make It Rain attacks from Choice Specs Gholdengo, then dumps the remaining EVs into Defense.

  • 28 Speed IVs allow Amoonguss to underspeed Brave nature Iron Hands and Kingambit inside of Trick Room but otherwise retains more Speed for use outside of Trick Room.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• With good bulk, a solid defensive typing, and access to Spore, Clear Smog, and Regenerator, Amoonguss is a fantastic support and disruptor option.

  • Clear Smog: This prevents Amoonguss from getting set up on unless the opponent is Steel-type or has a Substitute up.

  • Hex: Hex both punishes foes put to sleep by Spore and hits Air Balloon Gholdengo and Flutter Mane.

  • Stomping Tantrum: Stomping Tantrum deals decent damage to Gholdengo and Magnezone.

Items

  • Leftovers: Leftovers gives Amoonguss longevity outside of Synthesis and Regenerator.

  • Black Sludge: Black Sludge is a great way to get around Item Clause if Leftovers is already in use. Note, if Amoonguss Terastallizes into a type that isn't Poison, it will take damage instead.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry is an alternative form of recovery, and it can be used regardless of Amoonguss's Tera type.

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves with residual damage, potentially breaking Focus Sash from foes like Great Tusk in the process.

Tera Types

  • Dark: While Amoonguss doesn't Terastallize often, Dark removes its weakness to Psychic-type attacks and makes Foul Play stronger, at the cost of gaining new weaknesses.

  • Poison: Poison removes Grass-type weaknesses, but makes Amoonguss weak to Ground-type attacks.

  • Steel: While it makes Amoonguss weak to Ground- and Fighting-type attacks, it also grants Amoonguss with a plethora of resistances, and it can be a tough Pokemon to break once foes like Breloom are KOed.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Amoonguss has a great defensive profile, and this set can help it even further with a slow switch to another teammate once per game.

  • Pivoting with Leaf Storm: After using Leaf Storm, Eject Pack activates and Amoonguss is switched out; however, it can also be activated by other stat drops, such as Intimidate and Special Defense drops from Shadow Ball.

Tera Types

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type grants a Psychic-type immunity, along with a STAB Foul Play.

  • Poison: A Poison Tera type removes Amoonguss's Ice-, Fire-, and Flying-type weaknesses; and makes Clear Smog stronger due to its Base Power being increased to 60 along with the bonus STAB; however this increases its vulnerability to Ground-type attacks.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type takes advantage of Leaf Storm's high Base Power to make it hit even harder, in addition to now resisting Ground-type attacks from the likes of Garchomp and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Tera Steel lets Haxorus gain set up opportunites versus Pokemon such as Scream Tail, Noivern, and Staraptor. It also lets it resist First Impression from Slither Wing.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Mold Breaker Funny Moments Compilation
sets.description:
• With its workable Speed, sky-high Attack stat, and the ever-valuable Mold Breaker, Haxorus is notable as one of the few setup sweepers not bothered by Mimikyu or Unaware.

  • With one Dragon Dance, it can outspeed most unboosted foes, but Choice Scarf users still cause issues, notably Hydreigon and Play Rough Meowscarada.

  • Dragon Claw may be worth using in place of Outrage to avoid locking Haxorus in.

  • Earthquake is extremely valuable on Haxorus due to Mold Breaker nullifying Levitate and Earth Eater, allowing Haxorus to hit foes like Rotom-W and Hydreigon hard without the need to lock into Outrage, and giving it a way to hit Orthworm hard at all

Items

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Haxorus deal damage much more effectively at the cost of recoil

  • Lum Berry: Lum Berry lets Haxorus safely set up against a foe that may use crippling status moves such as Will-O-Wisp and Spore.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Steel grants good security against opposing Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-types.

  • Fairy: Fairy maximizes Haxorus's security against opposing Dragon-types, specifically.

  • Electric: Electric provides a surefire way of dealing with Dondozo thanks to Tera Blast.

We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: HARBINGER (Choice Item)
sets.description:
• With access to the incredible Levitate, Hydreigon sets itself apart from Roaring Moon as a dangerous offensive force that effectively utilizes Terastallization.

  • Flamethrower: Flamethrower is useful for hitting Steel-types such as Scizor and otherwise decent Dark Pulse switch-ins like Meowscarada.

  • Flash Cannon: This is Hydreigon’s best option to hit Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Flutter Mane.

Items

  • Choice Specs: If your team has another Scarf user, Choice Specs Hydreigon is a nuclear wallbreaker that can pummel unsuspecting teams.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf patches up Hydreigon’s somewhat lackluster Speed, allowing it to threaten a wider portion of the metagame with its high-powered attacks.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type can be used to get around the many Dragon and Fairy-types that try to revenge kill Hydreigon, though it is still vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy has great synergy with Hydreigon's former typing, making it do especially well against Great Tusk.

  • Dark: Tera-boosted Dark Pulse is an absurdly powerful weapon, and when coupled with its flinch rate, Tera Dark Hydreigon can potentially muscle its way out of otherwise hopeless situations.

  • Fire: Terastallizing into the fire typing will grant Hydreigon a resistance to Fairy-types while removing its weakness to Fighting-types and giving it a good move to hit Steel-types with. However, unlike Tera Steel it does not grant a resistance to Dragon, and it also gives Hydreigon a few new weaknesses.

sets.name: Versatile Attacker
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's useful support movepool can add quite a bit of unpredictability to its offensive potential.

  • Note that this Hydreigon is fully capable of running three attacking moves with one support move.

  • Substitute: Substitute is excellent for scouting Terastallization and punishes common status users such as Yawn Dondozo.

  • Thunder Wave: When Terastallizing Hydreigon, Thunder Wave is often the safest move against other faster Dragon-types that Terastallize, such as Dragapult and Salamence.

  • Taunt: This is good for getting the edge against defensive foes such as Clodsire.

  • Nasty Plot: Nasty Plot makes Hydreigon a surprisingly dangerous sweeper against slower teams.

Tera Types

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type has fantastic synergy with Levitate, helping Hydreigon against Dragon- and Fairy-types without the dreaded Ground weakness.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Hydreigon a great matchup against Dragon-types and Great Tusk.

  • Poison: With a Poison Tera type, Hydreigon can do well against Fairy-types without fear of powerful Fighting-type attacks.

  • Dark: Since so few Pokemon resist Dark-type attacks, this is a good Tera type for cleaning up late game.

  • Fire: When using Flamethrower, a Fire Tera type is handy for both the Fairy resistance and a better matchup against Kingambit.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Substitute, Leftovers's extra bit of recovery helps reduce its risk.

  • Life Orb: A simple power boost still comes in handy, even if only using two attacks.

  • Black Glasses: If a teammate is already using Life Orb, Black Glasses is a good compromise.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description:
• Hydreigon's new access to Stealth Rock makes it a surprisingly effective offensive support Pokemon.

  • Taunt: Taunt effectively shuts down common support leads like Hippowdon and Clodsire.

  • Thunder Wave: This is a powerful deterrent against offensive foes and can even stop sweepers in emergency situations when used with Focus Sash.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Thanks to Levitate, a Steel Tera type is an incredible defensive typing for Hydreigon, giving it an advantage over Fairy- and Dragon-types.

  • Poison: Tera Poison is a good alternative to Steel, with fewer resistances but an important Fighting-type resistance.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type gives Hydreigon the potential to effectively lead against Great Tusk.

  • Dark: If using Life Orb, boosting Dark-type attacks can make for some surprising late-game cleaning.

  • Fire: Fire-type Hydreigon is better against Kingambit and Fairy-types.

Items

  • Leftovers: If using Taunt, Leftovers is the best choice for giving Hydreigon longevity against defensive foes such as Corviknight.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash makes setting up Stealth Rock a much easier task against offensive teams. Be warned that it doesn't stop Dragapult's Dragon Darts.

  • Life Orb: Life Orb lets Hydreigon be played more offensively if setting Stealth Rock isn't needed.

  • Dark Glasses: Dark Glasses work if a teammate is using Life Orb.

vgc2023.overview:
• Hydreigon is a strong contender for the title of best Pokemon in the Series 1 metagame thanks to its diverse movepool and high damage output.

  • Terastallization proves to be a boon for Hydreigon, as it can get rid of its ever-burdening Fairy-type weakness by changing to much more beneficial types such as Steel.

  • Hydreigon has a good offensive typing, leaving few Pokemon able to switch in safely. It is one of the best checks to Gholdengo and also pairs well with it, forming a fundamentally powerful core when used with Tailwind support from Murkrow. Armarouge and Garchomp also synergize well with Hydreigon, covering for Steel-types, which it may not be able to damage effectively depending on its Tera type. Hydreigon can, however, struggle against damage reduction such as Snarl and Light Screen, with the latter coming especially from Grimmsnarl, which can easily take its STAB moves and OHKO it back with Spirit Break if Hydreigon is not Terastallized. Repeated usage of Draco Meteor can also make Hydreigon deal unimpressive amounts of damage, but this can be counteracted with Haze from Murkrow, allowing it to continue dealing devastating damage.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
• Tailwind allows Hydreigon to support allies such as Armarouge and Sylveon, forming strong offensive combinations. The third moveslot depends on Hydreigon's Tera Type and can be changed accordingly. Protect is utilized on teams with a different primary Tailwind setter such as Murkrow, but Hydreigon can still be kept as a secondary setter.

  • Life Orb lets Hydreigon dish out consistent damage without the need to set up.

  • The Steel Tera type synergizes wonderfully with Hydreigon's original typing and Levitate, allowing it to resist a plethora of common types such as Fairy, Ground, and, Dragon. This makes Hydreigon one of the best checks to Tera Ground Garchomp, which cannot hit Hydreigon with Earthquake and deals minimal damage to it with Dragon Claw and Rock Slide. A Fire Tera type allows Hydreigon to beat opposing Tera Steel Pokemon such as Hydreigon and Salamence. The Poison Tera type lets Hydreigon maintain the resistance to Fairy that Steel and Fire possess while also gaining an additional resistance to Fighting, crucial against the likes of Annihilape, Hariyama, and Close Combat Lycanroc. It is only left with Psychic as a relevant weakness, synergizing well with its original Dark typing. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon for coverage against Fairy-types on sets that use Tera Poison.

sets.name: Scope Lens
sets.description:
• Heat Wave is a great coverage move to deal with Steel-types that can withstand Draco Meteor such as Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Scope Lens takes advantage of the +2 critical hit rate from Focus Energy, allowing Hydreigon to always critical hit, especially through Draco Meteor Special Attack drops and other means of damage reduction such as Light Screen.

  • A Timid nature lets Hydreigon speed tie other Hydreigon as the raw power it gains from having the ability to always critical hit is enough. A Modest nature can, however, be utilized on teams with good methods of speed control such as Tailwind from Murkrow.

  • The Fire Tera type powers up Hydreigon's Heat Wave, letting it OHKO Kingambit on a critical hit and nearly OHKO Amoonguss, and gives Hydreigon a Fairy resistance.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Snarl is an immensely useful tool for reducing the damage dealt by strong special attackers such as Gholdengo, Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force Armarouge, and opposing Hydreigon.

  • Flash Cannon in combination with the Steel Tera type is used as a way to keep Fairy-types such as Grimmsnarl and Sylveon in check. Heat Wave is used as coverage to hit opposing Steel-types, but Dark Pulse is usually preferred over it for its ability to deal consistent damage to most other types overall.

  • Assault Vest makes Hydreigon a very potent sponge against special moves when combined with its ability to use Snarl for further reduction, especially for its teammates. Its high Special Attack lets it deal respectable damage despite running a more support-oriented set.

  • The Speed EVs allow Hydreigon to outrun maximum Speed Timid Gholdengo, and as a result, Armarouge of all Speed investments, allowing it to immediately use Snarl and lower their damage output. The Special Attack EVs let it always 2HKO maximum HP and 4 Special Defense Armarouge and uninvested Gholdengo with Dark Pulse. The Special Defense EVs make -1 Modest maximum Special Attack Choice Specs Gholdengo's Shadow Ball only a possible 5HKO on Tera Steel Hydreigon, while Make It Rain rocks a petty chance to even 7HKO. -1 Armarouge Aura Sphere also only has about a 50% chance to 4HKO Hydreigon. Note that Hydreigon should not be Terastallized against Armarouge to maintain the Fire resistance and Psychic immunity, as it is still weak to Aura Sphere when Terastallized. Opposing Tera Fire Hydreigon never OHKOes Tera Steel Hydreigon with Life Orb Heat Wave when spread damage is accounted for, allowing Hydreigon to retaliate with Snarl. The physical bulk allows Hydreigon to never be 2HKOed by maximum Attack Adamant Annihilape Drain Punch and Jolly maximum Attack Garchomp Brick Break.

  • Steel Tera type is the best defensive type for Hydreigon, allowing it to hard check most special attackers such as Gholdengo and Sylveon while holding its own against Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl. Poison Tera type, on the other hand, lets Hydreigon maintain the Fairy resistance that Steel gives it while also awarding it an additional resistance to Fighting in the face of Pokemon such as Annihilape and Hariyama. Tera Blast should be used instead of Flash Cannon to hit Fairy-types on Tera Poison sets.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Quiver Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
• Volcarona's access to Quiver Dance makes it a more effective sweeper than Iron Moth.

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is the best coverage option for Volcarona, as it helps it deal with Water-type Pokémon, as well as recover a good amount of HP.

  • Water Tera Blast: Water-type Tera Blast helps Volcarona deal with Pokemon like Skeledirge, Ceruledge, and other Volcarona. Volcarona with Bug Buzz can also be used, as it is a very powerful STAB move and helps Volcarona deal with Hydreigon.

  • Rock Tera Blast: Despite Rock being a poor defensive typing, Tera Rock allows Volcarona to cover Dragonite and Skeledirge with one move.

Tera Types

  • Water: Terastallizing into the Water typing nullifies Volcarona's most common weakness in Rock-type. Tera Blast damages Hydreigon decently prior to Terastallizing. Water-type Tera Blast is also the best option Volcarona has to hit Skeledirge.

  • Grass: The Grass typing strengthens Giga Drain and nullifies Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, most notably helping against Dondozo and Rotom-W.

  • Rock: Tera Rock is Volcarona's best bet against Skeledirge and Dragonite, especially with the useful Extreme Speed resistance. When used with Hippowdon's Sand Stream, it also makes Volcarona quite specially bulky.

  • Fire: Terastallizing into Fire typing makes Volcarona's Fire Blast even more powerful.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: It is the best option on Volcarona, as it circumvents its crippling Stealth Rock weakness.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry helps Volcarona accrue boosts more easily with Quiver Dance and lets it avoid being 2HKOed by Mimikyu and Dragonite.

  • Life Orb: This is the most reliable tool for helping Volcarona sweep in the late-game.

sets.name: Bulkarona
sets.description:
• With recovery and massive investments in bulk, Volcarona is capable of setting up multiple Quiver Dances, giving it new opportunities to sweep.

  • Tera Blast: Even before Terastallization, Tera Blast can come in handy for hitting Roaring Moon and Hydreigon.

  • Giga Drain: Giga Drain is Volcarona's best shot at beating Water-types such as Rotom-W and Palafin; note that Dondozo is not 2HKOed.

  • Will-O-Wisp: Burning foes is great for punishing boosting physical attackers that may Terastallize, such as Kingambit or Roaring Moon.

  • Bug Buzz: This is Volcarona's best tool against foes behind a Substitute, and hits Roaring Moon and Hydreigon hard.

  • Substitute: Though it can be difficult to fit-in, Substitute allows Volcarona to punish users of status moves, such as sleep moves from Breloom and Toxic from Water Absorb Clodsire.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Volcarona punish foes like Choice Band Dragapult and Roaring Moon, at the cost of being far more vulnerable to Tera Steel Dragons and Kingambit.

  • Water: Besides removing all of Volcarona's old weaknesses, a Water Tera type also 2HKOes Skeledirge with Tera Blast.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera type, Volcarona can now 2HKO most Dondozo with Giga Drain and is better insulated against Rotom-W revenge kills.

  • Flying: While a Flying Tera Type isn't a huge help defensively, the immunity to Fissure makes Volcarona better equipped to handle Dondozo.

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type simply gives Fiery Dance more power, and makes sense if not using Tera Blast.

Items

  • Heavy-Duty Boots: Stealth Rock is common enough that this is the safest item for Volcarona to hold.

  • Sitrus Berry: Sitrus Berry gives Volcarona more durability against teams that lack hazards.

  • Safety Goggles: This allows Volcarona to handle Spore from Breloom and Amoonguss without Terastallizing.

EV Spreads

  • 244 HP / 196 Def / 68 Spe with Bold: This spread outspeeds Meowscarada after Quiver Dance while maximizing Volcarona's physical bulk.

  • 244 HP / 188 Def / 76 Spe with Timid: This spread sacrifices some physical bulk for being able to outspeed Dragapult and Iron Bundle after one Quiver Dance.

sets.name: SOLAR FLARE (Choiced Attacker)
sets.description:
• While Iron Moth is the easier to justify Choice Item user, Volcarona is still an extremely powerful at doing this too, and can catch defensive threats off guard with it.

  • ** Fiery Dance**: With its high chance to boost Volcarona’s Special Attack, Fiery Dance is a potent cleaning tool.

  • Bug Buzz: Bug Buzz is a good secondary STAB move that allows Volcarona to hit foes hiding behind a substitute.

  • Overheat: Overheat deals good immediate damage, which can allow Volcarona to muscle past otherwise annoying walls.

  • Giga Drain: This is Volcarona’s best option to hit Dondozo.

  • Tera Blast: Tera Blast can be used with various Tera types to augment Volcarona’s coverage, helping it get around its somewhat limited movepool.

  • U-turn: Since Stealth Rock is relatively less common in Battle Stadium Singles, Volcarona can serve as a rather reliable pivot with U-turn.

Items

  • Choice Specs: With the extra power offered by Choice Specs, Volcarona becomes even more difficult to wall, even potentially breaking through some resists with its attacks.

  • Choice Scarf: Choice Scarf Volcarona outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, allowing it to revenge kill and pivot very effectively.

Tera Types

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type slightly improves Volcarona’s defensive profile while boosting Fiery Dance and Overheat even further, allowing it to grab some surprising KOs.

  • Fairy: When paired with Tera Blast, a Fairy Tera type allows Volcarona to better handle the many Dragon-types in the metagame; notably, it is Volcarona's best option for beating Dragonite and Dragapult.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type allows Volcarona to resist the many Water-type attacks aimed at it and gives it a better chance at breaking past Dondozo.

  • Rock: Despite the poor defensive typing, Tera Rock allows Volcarona to cover both Dragonite and Skeledirge. When paired with Hippowdon, it also makes revenge killing Volcarona with Special Attackers fairly difficult.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Volcarona's great defensive typing and solid bulk makes it a good defensive pivot for threats such as non-Stakeout Iron Valiant and Slither Wing while checking Iron Bundle and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. Morning Sun gives Volcarona a boosted recovery under Desolate Land, and Will-O-Wisp enables Volcarona to cripple its switch-ins. The 32 Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outpace and burn uninvested Garchomp with Will-O-Wisp. Specially defensive walls like Ice Scales Corviknight appreciate Volcarona's ability to switch into to mixed threats like Iron Valiant. Specially offensive Ghosts like Dragapult and Gholdengo also appreciate Volcarona's ability to spread burns and allow them to utilize Hex at full power. Heavy-Duty Boots is vital for Volcarona's longevity, so it is recommended to pair Volcarona with a Knock Off switchin like Great Tusk or Iron Hands to mitigate the chance of being vulnerable to entry hazards.

sets.name: Offensive Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona makes for a threatening late-game sweeper thanks to Quiver Dance, strong coverage moves, and a decent defensive profile. Fire Blast can be slotted over Flamethrower to hit much harder, notably OHKOing most variants of Gholdengo, but Flamethrower is usually better because of its consistency. Volcarona can utilize Giga Drain with Tera Grass to hit a plethora of Water-type Pokemon like Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Urshifu-R hard, in addition to Ground- and Rock-types such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Hidden Power Ground and Tera Ground help Volcarona bypass checks like Toxapex and Heatran after slight chip damage while also removing Volcaronra’s glaring Rock weakness. Psychic with Tera Psychic allows Volcarona to break through Clodsire and Toxapex more reliably, but it is inferior to either of the previously mentioned Tera types due to its greater vulnerability to being revenge killed, and it leaves Volcarona completely stonewalled by Heatran. Flame Body can threaten to burn physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta, crippling them. Maximum Speed investment and a Timid Nature lets Volcarona outrun Choice Scarf users such as Tapu Lele and Urshifu-R after a boost. Modest can be run to hit walls like Clodsire and Toxapex harder, but it leaves Volcarona much more vulnerable to the aforementioned Choice Scarf users. Volcarona’s defensive utility is appreciated by allies such as Urshifu-R and Kingambit, as it can check dangerous Fighting-types like Iron Valiant and Zamazenta in a pinch. Bulky Dragon-types like Dragonite and Garchomp can use it as setup fodder—with the latter additionally threatening Volcarona’s longevity with Toxic—so allies that can handle them such as Ferrothorn and Rotom-W are great partners to support Volcarona in its sweep. Heatran and Toxapex wall Volcarona if it doesn’t have Hidden Power Ground, so teammates like that can check them such as Garchomp and the aforementioned Rotom-W are much appreciated. Heatran also makes for a great ally, as it can eliminate or cripple Toxapex, Clodsire, and Skeledirge, which clears the way for Volcarona to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Bulky Quiver Dance
sets.description: Volcarona distinguishes itself as a bulky setup sweeper by boasting reliable recovery, Quiver Dance, and being able to check Zamazenta and Iron Valiant with its unique typing. Bug Buzz can hit Mega Gyarados, Garchomp, and Mega Latias harder, but Giga Drain can be run to hit Water-types such as Urshifu-R, Gastrodon, and Rotom-W. Psychic can also be ran to threaten Clodsire and Toxapex. Will-O-Wisp makes Volcarona more utility-oriented, threatening physical attackers like Zamazenta and Dragonite with a burn more reliably, crippling them. However, the lack of coverage leaves Volcarona walled easily by most Fire-resistant Pokemon. The given Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outspeed Dragapult after a Quiver Dance, with the rest invested in HP and Defense so that it will always be 3HKOed by Zamazenta and defensive Great Tusk’s Earthquake. Volcarona struggles with status conditions, as they can hinder its ability to check threats like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant in the long term, thus status absorbers like Gliscor and Toxapex make good partners; the former provides Defog support, a Knock Off absorber, and a Heatran check, and the latter helps prepare Volcarona’s sweep with Knock Off and status inducement. Volcarona can be easily exploited by setup sweepers like Garchomp, Dragapult, Mega Tyranitar, and Dragonite, and so checks like Rotom-W, Kingambit, Ferrothorn, and Tapu Lele can help to alleviate these matchups.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Fast Utility
sets.description:
Tera Ghost allows Talonflame to check Maushold and Swords Dance Lucario, spinblock, and remove its weakness to Stealth Rock if it loses its item. It also gives Talonflame an emergency immunity to Boomburst from Noivern and Toxtricity and lets Taunt sets beat Quagsire and Gastrodon.

Tera Steel instead lets Talonflame gain a resistance to Stealth Rock and Extreme Speed, as well as an immunity to Toxic and poison, which helps against Grafaiai. It can also let it serve as a serviceable Staraptor switch-in, although it must beware of Close Combat. It must also be careful to not Terastallize if it still needs to handle Slither Wing.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Florges leverages its great defensive typing, high PP recovery move in Wish, and Fur Coat to blanket check physical threats such as Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant. Synthesis gives Florges more recovery PP at the cost of making Wish less safe to use. Calm Mind can turn Florges into a late-game wincon. Leftovers bolsters Florges's recovery, while Heavy-Duty Boots reduces the damage it takes from frequent switches in. Trick + Choice Scarf Florges can cripple foes like Corviknight and set up on them with Calm Mind; however, it forgoes Wish's recovery PP for this. Defensive partners like Ice Scales Corviknight and Toxapex can help Florges by switching into Steel- and Poison-types that threaten it, like Gholdengo and Iron Moth; in return, they appreciate Florges switching into physical attackers like Iron Hands and Roaring Moon for them. Offensive partners like Kingambit and Dragapult appreciate Florges's Wish giving them more chances to wallbreak.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With its good natural bulk, Sylveon can serve as a potent attacker and decent revenge killer.

  • Tera BlastTera Blast serves as a good alternate STAB attack once Sylveon has Terastallized, providing highly valuable coverage against the Steel-types that could otherwise exploit it, like Scizor. It also gets around potential users of Throat Chop before Terastallization, such as Roaring Moon.

  • Psyshock: This is Sylveon's best shot of dealing with Iron Moth.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball hits foes such as Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo super effectively, and it means Sylveon does not have to Terastallize to hit Gholdengo for good damage.

  • Quick Attack: Though it is weak, Quick Attack gives valuable priority for picking off weakened threats, and thanks to Pixilate, surprise users of Tera Ghost aren't able to absorb it.

  • Hyper Beam: Despite the serious risks from the recharge turn, Hyper Beam's extreme power makes it a good filler move.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest lets even offensive Sylveon be specially resilient.

  • Choice Specs: With the boost from Choice Specs, Sylveon is a surprisingly potent wallbreaker, making the most out of its many opportunities to switch in.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA: This spread capitalizes on Sylveon's good natural bulk while maximizing its power.

  • 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe: While no bulk investment makes Sylveon more difficult to safely get in, Speed investment allows it to outrun and threaten a wider range of foes, such as Scizor and Corviknight.

Tera Types

  • Fire: Tera Fire allows Sylveon to break past troublesome Steel-types, like Gholdengo and Kingambit.

  • Fairy: Getting an extra boost on Hyper Voice and Hyper Beam makes Choice Specs Sylveon far more difficult to wall, with even resists such as Gholdengo and physically defensive Skeledirge getting 2HKOed by Hyper Voice!

sets.name: CUTESY CRUSADER (Defensive)
sets.description:
• With its good bulk and Special Attack, Sylveon is quite a dangerous threat and is also hard to take down.

  • Tera Blast: Beyond just Terastallization, Sylveon can optionally use it as its sole attacking move, since Pixilate will make it a Fairy-type attack before Terastallizing.

  • Hyper Voice: This gives Sylveon a reliable Fairy-type attack even when Terastallized.

  • Wish: Wish can be used to keep Sylveon healthy, as well as its teammates.

  • Shadow Ball: Shadow Ball offers important coverage on Gholdengo without demanding that Sylveon Terastallize.

  • Quick Attack Though weak, Quick Attack can be very helpful for finishing off foes that have hung on against Sylveon or its teammates, and thanks to Pixilate, Ghost-types cannot safely switch in to absorb the move.

Tera Types

  • Fire: A Fire Tera type grants Sylveon resistances to Steel and Fairy, allowing it to take on foes it would otherwise have to run from, such as Gholdengo.

  • Water: Tera Water is a great mono-attacking option, making it ideal if only running Tera Blast to do decently well against Steel-types.

vgc2023.overview:
• Sylveon is a great Pokemon in Series 1 thanks to a strong Pixilate-boosted Hyper Voice, potentially further boosted by Throat Spray and Calm Mind.Its Fairy typing is especially strong in a metagame with plenty of good Dark-, Dragon-, and Fighting-types like Grimmsnarl, Hydreigon, Hariyama, and Annihilape.

  • Sylveon's Speed means that it can effectively take advantage of both Trick Room and Tailwind from Pokemon like Amrarouge and Murkrow; 212 Speed EVs, taken from Sylveon's HP, can be run on Tailwind teams to outpace Dragapult.

  • Sylveon can struggle against Fire-types like Ceruledge and Armarouge, which makes Pokemon like Rotom-W, Paldean Tauros-A, and Dragonite good teammates. Sylveon also appreciates Pokemon like Ceruledge and Garchomp that can handle Gholdengo.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Tera Blast + Fire Tera type gives Sylveon a strong matchup against Steel-types like Gholdengo and Tera Steel Hydreigon. When not Terastallized, Tera Blast is boosted by Pixiliate and is still useful for dealing damage when faced by Wide Guard users like Armarouge. Fairy Tera type makes Sylveon's Hyper Voice even more powerful, letting it 2HKO even naturally bulky Pokemon like Kingambit and Hatterene; this can be used over Fire Tera type on teams that can afford the loss in effectiveness against Steel-types like Gholdengo. Ground Tera type is an option that lets Sylveon hit opposing Fire-types like Ceruledge and Armarouge hard, retain good damage against Steel-types, and avoid a burdensome weakness to Garchomp, though Sylveon strongly values the resistance to Steel that a Fire Tera type grants.

  • Substitute is good for blocking Amoonguss's Spore, preventing its Clear Smog from resetting Sylveon's stat boosts, and taking advantage of defensive play. Quick Attack is an option that can prove particularly useful against Tailwind teams, picking off Pokemon brought down to their Focus Sash like Murkrow and Kilowattrel, as well as other weakened Pokemon.

  • Calm Mind is an option that can be particularly potent on bulkier teams with damage mitigation from Pokemon like Gyarados and Grimmsnarl to help Sylveon set up.

  • Throat Spray is a no-drawback way of improving Sylveon's offense; a +1 Hyper Voice will 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. Life Orb lets Sylveon immediately 2HKO or nearly 2HKO most offensive Pokemon at the cost of recoil that could put it in range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake. Leftovers is good alongside Calm Mind on bulkier teams where Sylveon wants to stick around longer. Safety Goggles grants Sylveon immunity to Amoonguss's Spore.

  • On Tailwind teams Sylveon can run 212 Speed EVs, taken from its HP stat, to outpace Dragapult.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs is Sylveon's most immediately powerful set, it can 2HKO most offensive Pokemon that do not resist Fairy. It's much more immediately powerful than Throat Spray Sylveon and a bit stronger than Life Orb Sylveon without wearing itself down with recoil, helping it stay out of range of attacks like Tera Ground Garchomp's Earthquake.

  • Tera Blast + a Fire Tera Type lets Sylveon hit Fairy-resistant foes like Gholdengo and Amoonguss hard, and the typing is defensively useful against the former. Tera Blast is also useful by itself in the face of Wide Guard, giving Sylveon an option besides Hyper Beam, which has a turn of recharge, for a single target Fairy-type attack.

  • Shadow Ball hits Armarouge, Ceruledge, and Skeledirge, which resist Fairy, and is a strong option against Gholdengo and Gengar if Terastallizing is off the table.

  • Hyper Beam OHKOes bulky Pokemon like Rotom-W and Kingambit that can take Hyper Voice.

  • 212 Speed EVs, taken from Sylveon's HP stat, let it outpace Dragapult on Tailwind teams.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Frisk lets Noivern scout for items such as Choice Scarf from Sandy Shocks. Infiltrator can be used to hit Gengar with Draco Meteor through Substitute and be more threatening versus dual screens teams. Tera Normal gives Noivern a huge power boost on Boomburst, letting it guarantee an OHKO versus Quagsire.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: 52 Speed EVs allows Oricorio-Pom-Pom to outspeed Talonflame after a Quiver Dance, with the remaining EVs being invested in HP and Defense to take hits more easily from priority users like Lokix, Slither Wing, and Lucario. Tera Ground transforms Revelation Dance into a Ground-type attack, hitting foes like Tinkaton, Tyranitar, and Sandy Shocks for super effective damage.

sets.name: Choice Band (Rock)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Water)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Toxapex utilizes its remarkable special bulk and valuable defensive typing to check offensive threats such as Chi-Yu, Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and non-Mold Breaker Iron Bundle. The combination of Toxic + Haze lets Toxapex shut down and eventually beat setup sweepers that try to overwhelm it such as Dragonite, Ceruledge, and Volcarona. Liquidation pressures Toxic-immune foes like Clodsire and Kingambit. Toxic Spikes is an option to spread status more easily, which works well with Hex users such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Hippowdon can check threatening foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands for it; Corviknight's Defog also relieves entry hazard pressure from Toxapex if not running Heavy-Duty Boots, while Hippowdon's Stealth Rock works well with Toxapex's poison to spread further passive damage.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Toxapex acts as a fantastic defensive pivot on bulkier playstyles courtesy of its excellent bulk and Regenerator. This allows it to scout Choice-locked Pokemon such as Dragapult and Zamazenta and pivot around powerful attackers such as Iron Valiant. Scald and Knock Off allow Toxapex to meaningfully threaten foes and make progress by either causing crippling status or removing the foe's item respectively, while Toxic takes advantage of Toxapex's excellent bulk and Regenerator, putting foes on a timer for its teammates. Haze removes boosts from the likes of Dragon Dance Dragapult and Espathra. Other options such as Toxic Spikes and Baneful Bunker can be explored over either Toxic or Haze, with the intent to cripple offensive teams or maximize Toxapex's ability to scout and pivot, respectively. However, removing Toxic leaves Toxapex worse off against common Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Rotom-W, while removing Haze makes it harder to handle setup sweepers. Although Toxapex rarely Terastallizes, Tera Dragon ensures Rotom-W's Volt Switch never outdamages Regenerator while also removing its Ground and Electric weaknesses against the likes of Great Tusk and Tapu Koko. The EV spread maximizes Toxapex's physical Bulk while allowing it to survive two Scorching Sands from Mega Charizard Y. Toxapex fits best on defensively oriented teams, which don't mind its passivity and can make up for any of its defensive shortcomings. Toxapex pairs well with Unaware Pokemon such as Skeledirge and Clodsire, which can handle setup sweepers that Toxapex falters to such as Kingambit and Gholdengo. In return, Toxapex sponges various weaker attacks using Regenerator from the likes of Gastrodon and Rotom-W. Toxapex dislikes losing its item, as it can easily be pushed into KO range against wallbreakers such as Zamazenta and Dragapult alongside entry hazards. As such, Pokemon that can generally withstand Knock Off well, such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor, pair excellently with it. Tornadus-T in particular makes for a great partner, as it can use Regenerator alongside Toxapex, pivoting between each other to handle Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Garganacl. Toxapex appreciates extra insurance against strong special attackers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. As such, Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Heatran pair well, especially since Toxapex can switch into the Shadow Balls and Focus Blasts aimed that them respectively.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Salazzle should rarely be Terastillized, as it loses its 4x resistance to First Impression from Slither Wing and Lokix and doesn't notably benefit from any type change.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: The given Speed EVs allow Tsareena to outspeed Kilowattrel after a Rapid Spin. Although Tsareena should Terastallize rarely, Tera Steel helps Tsareena act as an emergency check to Staraptor and Gengar by tanking Brave Bird and Sludge Bomb respectively and allowing it to decently chip them.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Tsareena to outspeed Iron Bundle under Tailwind, retain enough Attack to OHKO 252 HP Palafin-Hero with Power Whip, then invests the remaining EVs in HP.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description: 24 Speed EVs are to outrun Modest Toxtricity after a Rapid Spin, Mismagius and Cryogonal at +2, and Choice Scarf Passimian at +3 Speed.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Ghost)

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Thanks to Disguise, Mimikyu is a premier revenge killer and sweeper in Battle Stadium Singles, being particularly apt at revenge killing Flutter Mane with Shadow Sneak.

  • Drain Punch: If using Tera Fighting, Drain Punch is a good coverage move against Steel-types such as Kingambit and Iron Treads.

  • Fire Tera Blast: Tera Blast is a risky option due to making your team commit to Terastallizing Mimikyu, but it can be worth it for muscling through Mimikyu's usual checks, such as Corviknight and Tera Steel Pokemon.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: The extra damage on Shadow Sneak gives Mimikyu an easier time sweeping late-game.

  • Fighting: The boosted power of Drain Punch gives Mimikyu a far better matchup against Kingambit.

  • Fairy: A boosted Play Rough lets Mimikyu clean through weakened bulky Pokemon like Dondozo more easily.

  • Fire: With Tera Blast, Jolly Mimikyu has a 75% chance to OHKO Corviknight after Swords Dance, which means most other Steel-types will have a far more difficult time dealing with Mimikyu.

  • Electric: While not as effective against Steel-types as Tera Fire, it still deals massive damage to Corviknight, and gives Mimikyu better chip damage to Dondozo.

  • Normal: Tera Normal doesn't help Mimikyu offensively and makes Mimikyu vulnerable to Mach Punch and Dragon Darts, making it a niche option. However, it does severely punish Dragapult if it uses Phantom Force.

sets.name: Curse Stall
sets.description:
• The combination of Curse, Substitute, and Pain Split is devastating against key defensive Pokemon such as Garganacl and Dondozo.

  • Shadow Claw versus Play Rough: Shadow Claw is Mimikyu's best shot at dealing damage to Gholdengo, at the cost of doing poorly against Normal-types. While it will make Mimikyu nearly helpless against Gholdengo, Play Rough lets Mimikyu deal serious damage to Dragon-types and Great Tusk.

  • Taunt: Taunt does an even better job of shutting down defensive foes, but makes Mimikyu totally useless against Gholdengo.

Tera Types

  • Ghost / Fairy: Terastallizing this Mimikyu for extra damage output is fairly situational, but getting a bit of extra power can help late game.

  • Flying: Against common users of Fissure such as Dondozo, this gives Mimikyu a situational way to stall them out more easily while healthy.

Items

  • Figy Berry: Figy Berry and it's other counterparts give Mimikyu another method of healing after using Substitute enough times.

  • Bright Powder: While not particularly reliable, even one miss against Mimikyu can be devestating.

sets.name: Trick Scarf
sets.description:
• Mimikyu might seem like an odd user of Choice Scarf with its low offenses, but with Trick and Disguise, it becomes a very disruptive Pokemon against defensive foes like Dondozo and Corviknight.

  • Shadow Sneak: Shadow Sneak is a reasonable option to give Mimikyu priority after using Trick, which is especially helpful against Flutter Mane.

  • Wood Hammer hits Water-types such as Rotom-W and Iron Bundle very hard.

  • Thunder Wave, Will-O-Wisp, and Curse: Thunder Wave, Will-O-Wisp, or Curse let Mimikyu further disrupt Pokemon after using Trick, or can be used as an emergency way to stop a sweeper while still holding Choice Scarf.

  • Using a neutral Nature with a mint: Mimikyu should have a neutral nature with a Jolly Mint used on it. This way, Mimikyu can't be confused by eating any Berry after using Trick.

Other Options

  • Destiny Bond: Mimikyu's good Speed makes it a good option for making trades with Destiny Bond.

Tera Types

  • Ghost: Tera Ghost gives Mimikyu a good chance to OHKO Dragapult with Shadow Claw.

  • Grass: With Wood Hammer being boosted, Mimikyu OHKOes offensive Rotom-W.

  • Normal: While this makes Mimikyu far more vulnerable to Breloom, it is useful for catching other Ghost-types such as Flutter Mane off guard.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Physically defensive Corviknight is a fantastic check to dangerous attackers like Garchomp, Roaring Moon, and Dragonite an effective slow pivot; and one of the few viable entry hazard removers. The choice between Brave Bird and Body Press comes down to team need; Brave Bird nails Great Tusk and has no immunities, while Body Press is Corviknight's best option against Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Leftovers is the preferred item to provide extra longevity, but Rocky Helmet can further punish physical attackers, especially on weak hits like Scizor's and Meowscarada's U-turn. Tera Water serves as an emergency check to dangerous Fire-types like Cinderace, while Tera Ground surprises Iron Hand.

Corviknight is a fantastic slow pivot, making it a great partner for frail-but-powerful teammates like Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant. It is also one of the few viable Defoggers, allowing it to partner up with teammates like Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Volcarona that loathe Stealth Rock. Be warned, Corviknight is utterly unable to Defog against Gholdengo, so secondary entry hazard removal like Great Tusk and a reliable switch-in like Ting-Lu are recommended. Corviknight is unable to handle powerful physical Fire-types like Cinderace and Ceruledge and Electric-types like Iron Hands. Teammates that can cover these weaknesses like Dondozo and Great Tusk are wonderful partners. Its middling special bulk makes teammates like Slowking and Ting-Lu valuable. Slowking has the added benefit of being another slow pivot as well, while Ting-Lu forms a strong entry hazard core with Corviknight and threatens Gholdengo.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
• Corviknight's high physical bulk gives it a strong defensive presence in the tier. It is one of the few consistent counters to strong Ground-types like Great Tusk, physical attackers like Chien-Pao, and some special attackers like non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle. Furthermore, its access to Defog also makes it a solid entry hazard remover, though it struggles against Gholdengo.
  • Body Press provides Corviknight with a way to leverage its high Defense stat, doing significant damage to Fighting-weak Pokemon.
  • Brave Bird allows Corviknight to threaten Flutter Mane and Great Tusk. Alternatively, Iron Head can be used to threaten the former while avoiding recoil damage.
  • Maximum HP investment and enough Defense to check Chien-Pao is combined with Leftovers and 96 Special Defense EVs, which allows Corviknight to take two Mystical Fires from most Flutter Mane, as well as giving it the ability to take on non-Choice Specs Iron Bundle and weaker attacks like Freeze-Dry from Choice Specs Iron Bundle.
  • Tera Steel or Flying can be used to shed the weaknesses of Corviknight's dual typing: Tera Steel allows Corviknight to resist Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao, while Tera Flying allows Corviknight to resist Great Tusk's Fighting-type attacks. Depending on your choice, Terastallization also amplifies the power of either Iron Head or Brave Bird.
  • Corviknight works well as a part of a defensive core with Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Blissey, which can handle threats like Miraidon that obliterate Corviknight. Additionally, Corviknight makes a great partner for offensive threats like Chi-Yu, which appreciate a teammate that easily switches into Ting-Lu, or Great Tusk, which appreciates opposing Great Tusk being worn down.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• Specially defensive Corviknight can switch into foes like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Gholdengo, and Glimmora.
  • U-turn is used to make Corviknight an effective defensive pivot that can maintain momentum against foes that force it out such as Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Mirror Armor allows Corviknight to check Mystical Fire Flutter Mane, which would otherwise beat it. Alternatively, when paired with Pressure, Protect enables Corviknight to avoid being 2HKOed by Hydro Pump from Choice Specs Iron Bundle, as well as allowing Corviknight to deplete PP with Pressure more effectively.
  • Corviknight can use Tera Steel to get rid of its weakness to Electric and better take on Ice-type moves from Iron Bundle. Alternatively, it can opt to use Tera Ground to become immune to Miraidon's powerful Electro Drift.
  • Specially defensive Corviknight needs help dealing with strong physical wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao from teammates like Dondozo and Scream Tail. Furthermore, Pokemon that are especially threatened by Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, such as Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge, are able to rely on specially defensive Corviknight as a consistent switch-in.

sets.name: Specially Defensive (Flying)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!
