battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: OHKO Fisher
sets.description:
• With immense bulk, Yawn, and Unaware, Dondozo is not only an impressive defensive Pokemon, but one of the most dangerous OHKO fishers in the game.

  • Wave Crash: Despite the recoil, Wave Crash is the prefered option over Liquidation in most cases, purely for the damage output.

  • Protect: Protect is not only useful for scouting for unexpected Tera types, but pairs well with Yawn and Leftovers to give Dondozo more longevity.

  • Avalanche: It can be tricky to fit in, but Avalanche can be used to deal more consistent damage against Dragon-types.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type lets Dondozo take on powerful Dragon-type attacks much more easily, and is just a good defensive typing in general.

  • Grass: A Grass Tera type is useful enough for covering Dondozo's weaknesses, and the Spore immunity makes it capable of beating Breloom too.

  • Flying: Flying may seem like an odd Tera type, but it can lead to your Dondozo winning mirror matches thanks to the Fissure immunity.

EV Spreads

  • 252 Def / 252 SpD / 4 Spe: With Dondozo's massive HP stat, it's still able to take physical hits fairly well with this spread, while making it feasible to Yawn against special attacking threats such as Choice Scarf Hydreigon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe: This more extreme spread helps against powerful Tera users, with the ability to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Band Tera Dragon Dragapult's Dragon Darts with Leftovers. This comes at the cost of being much more vulnerable to weaker special attackers.

sets.name: BIG FLOPPA (Assault Vest)
sets.description:
• Dondozo’s good power and bulk lend it nicely to an Assault Vest set, and is particularly good at punishing otherwise troublesome special attackers such as Flutter Mane.

  • Avalanche: Avalanche punishes Flying- and Dragon-types with super effective coverage.

  • Body Press: This is valuable Fighting-type coverage for most foes that would otherwise be a good switch in to Dondozo, such as Meowscarada, Magnezone, and Kingambit.

  • Fissure: Fissure allows Dondozo to potentially cheese its way through something that might otherwise wall it.

  • Heavy Slam: Dondozo is heavy enough to deal serious damage to Fairy-types such as Mimikyu and Flutter Mane.

  • Earthquake: Earthquake offers more reliable Ground-type coverage at the cost of not being an instant KO like Fissure.

Tera Types

  • Grass: Tera Grass removes Dondozo’s usual set of weaknesses and allows it to absorb spore from the likes of Amoonguss, Breloom, and Brute Bonnet.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy grants Dondozo a new set of resistances to take advantage of with its phenomenal bulk and also grants it a powerful STAB to hit Dragon- and Fighting-types with if it runs Tera Blast.

  • Steel: When paired with Heavy Slam, Dondozo can now 2HKO Iron Bundle without Stealth Rock support, in addition to gaining a fantastic defensive typing.

  • Ground: Terastallizing into a Ground-type allows Dondozo to block the Electric-type attacks commonly aimed at it while also giving it STAB on Earthquake.

  • Dragon: Tera Dragon gives Dondozo a resistance to both Electric- and Water-type attacks, allowing it to stand up to Rotom-W much better.

  • Dark: Tera Dark allows Dondozo to better check Espathra by becoming immune to Lumina Crash and Stored Power.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description:
• With Unaware, Dondozo becomes an effective and difficult to break Curse user.

  • Fissure: Even with Curse being the point of this set, Dondozo can still effectively fish for OHKOs with Fissure when it's not in a favorable set-up position.

  • Avalanche: Many foes will Terrastallize into a Flying-type to avoid an expected Fissure, which makes Avalanche a particularly useful coverage move.

Tera Types

  • Fairy: The Dragon immunity that Tera Fairy provides makes setting up on powerful foes like Choice Band Dragapult and Roaring Moon much easier.

  • Grass: With a Grass Tera Type, Dondozo can effectively set up on Breloom and Brute Bonnet.

  • Flying: If using Fissure, Tera Flying is a good choice for potentially beating other Dondozo.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Dondozo is a great defensive Pokemon with its high physical bulk and typing, which allows it to wall physical attackers such as Zacian-C and Groudon. Spikes supports offensive teammates, while Haze stops foes like Swords Dance Zacian-C and Tidy Up Groudon from setting up. Knock Off removes items such as Covert Cloak and Leftovers, and Scald burns provide chip damage on foes. Flip Turn makes it easier to pivot into offensive teammates such as Miraidon, since Taunt, Dark-types, and Magic Bounce don't block it; alternatively, Parting Shot makes the foe easier to handle for Dondozo's teammates, but it's stopped by Taunt and Good as Gold. Heavy-Duty Boots, notably eases Dondozo's pivoting, while Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves such as U-turn and V-create. Covert Cloak protects against secondary effects like confusion from Zacian-C's Magical Torque and burns from Scald. Tera Fire allows Dondozo to resist Magical Torque and Grass-type moves from Zacian-C, and it maintains Dondozo's resistance to Fire-type moves such as V-create. Dondozo appreciates defensive teammates with typing synergy such as RegenVest Ting-Lu, which helps protect Dondozo from threatening Pokemon such as Miraidon.

sets.name: Prankster
sets.description: Prankster Dondozo with Haze can reliably check physical setup sweepers such as Zacian-C and Groudon thanks to its huge physical bulk. Entrainment forces out Pokemon dependent on their abilities, Encore can lock foes into unfavorable moves such as setup moves or V-create, and Glare debilitates fast attackers such as Zacian-C and Palkia-O. Parting Shot allows Dondozo to maintain momentum against opposing threats such as Miraidon with its priority pivoting and attack stat reduction, making it easier for teammates such as Ting-Lu to take hits from them; alternatively, Flip Turn provides a pivoting option unaffected by Taunt, Dark-types, and Magic Bounce. Heavy-Duty Boots, notably eases Dondozo's pivoting, while Covert Cloak protects it from status conditions from moves such as Nuzzle, Mortal Spin, and Magical Torque. Tera Fire improves Dondozo's matchup against Zacian-C with Grass-type coverage and lets it resist V-create and Magical Torque, whereas Tera Dark makes Dondozo immune to status moves from other Prankster users and improves its matchup against Ghost- and Dark-types. RegenVest Hisuian Goodra, Ting-Lu, and Fur Coat users synergize with Dondozo, covering threats such as Zacian-C, Groudon, and Palkia-O.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: Thanks to its massive physical bulk and ability, Unaware, Dondozo serves as a wall for physical setup sweepers, such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Dondozo also annoys rain teams, shutting down wallbreakers such as Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Mega Swampert. With Curse, Dondozo can also function as a late-game sweeper. Liquidation is preferred to Wave Crash given that it has more PP and does not incur recoil. However, Wave Crash can also be considered for its greater power. Leftovers is preferred to maximize longevity; however, Heavy-Duty Boots is worth consideration to fortify switches into entry hazards. Tera Grass transforms Dondozo's Electric and Grass weaknesses into resistances, turning common threats in Tapu Koko and Kartana into fodder and avoiding Leech Seed from Ferrothorn. Dondozo fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as they greatly appreciate its ability to wall physical setup sweepers. Given its mediocre special bulk, special walls such as Clodsire and Ting-Lu make for good teammates, as they can switch into special attackers such as Tapu Koko, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Choice Specs Dragapult. Gholdengo is another good teammate since it checks dangerous special wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant that can play around Dondozo's commonly paired special walls. Other Pokemon that can beat these threats include Mega Scizor and Clodsire.

ru.overview: The tier is still in its infancy and the metagame develops with each passing day. The sample set(s) provided below will be regularly updated until proper analyses are in the works. See it as a rough outline to get started and accustomed to what sets are commonly used.

sets.name: Offensive Spinner
sets.description: Despite having no effect in singles, Commander is used so Gardevoir can't Trace Storm Drain and wall Tatsugiri. Tera Steel turns the tide on Fairy-types such as Gardevoir and Sylveon. It also helps against Cryogonal's Freeze Dry.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• Annihilape is a solid setup sweeper due to its good Attack stat, decent bulk, and unresisted STAB combination. It can take advantage of Pokemon such as Corviknight, Blissey, and Clodsire.
  • Bulk Up gives Annihilape the potential to sweep while also making it progressively harder to KO.
  • Taunt allows Annihilape to stay healthy and also stops bulkier Pokemon such as Corviknight, Clodsire, and Toxapex from recovering their health. Rest can alternatively be used with Chesto Berry to get rid of status and recover health, but it fails when Electric Terrain is up.
  • Drain Punch allows Annihilape to recover health and damage foes such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads.
  • Rage Fist, along with Taunt, makes Annihilape incredibly threatening for slow walls such as Dondozo and Ting-Lu, as their attacks do little damage to Annilhilape while also boosting Rage Fist's power.
  • Tera Water allows Annihilape to take hits from special attackers such as Iron Bundle, Chi-Yu, and Flutter Mane while also letting it resist Flare Blitz from Koraidon.
  • Tera Fairy gives Annihilape an immunity against Dragon-type moves from Koraidon and Miraidon while also letting Annihilape take neutral damage from Ghost-type moves from Gholdengo and Flutter Mane, OHKOing them in return with boosted Rage Fist.
  • Annihilape reaches its full potential on dual screens hyper offense teams, where it can easily take hits while setting up.
  • Special walls such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight are good teammates on balance teams, as Pokemon such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle threaten Annihilape. Corviknight is also able to remove entry hazards for Annihilape. Kingambit as a teammate overwhelms Alomomola and Skeledirge, which are common checks to it and Annihilape.
  • Entry hazard setters such as Glimmora, Froslass, Toxapex, and Clodsire can lure in Corviknight, presenting Annhilape with a great setup opportunity by forcing Corviknight to either use Defog and activate Annihilape's Defiant or give Rage Fist a boost by attacking.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big new changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulky Taunt
sets.description:
• Thanks to great bulk and the dangerous Rage Fist, Annihilape is one of the premier bulky set-up sweepers of Battle Stadium Singles.

  • Taunt: Taunt helps you deal with annoying Pokemon like Dondozo, Will-O-Wisp Skeledirge, and Hippowdon, to mention a few, forcing them to attack and boost Rage Fist.

  • Vital Spirit: With Vital Spirit, Annihilape can absorb Spore from foes like Breloom, Brute Bonnet, and Amoonguss.

Tera Types

  • Steel: Steel turns Annihilape's Psychic and Fairy weakness into resistances, as well as being an excellent defensive type overall. It lets Annihilape set up freely on Amoonguss, gives it a better chance of defeating Flutter Mane, and resisting Flower Trick means Meowscarada has a much harder time revenge killing it.

  • Flying: Flying helps a lot to avoid Dondozo's Fissure, forcing it to attack with moves that boost Rage Fist. It also improves Annihilape's match-up against Great Tusk.

  • Fire: In addition to giving a useful resistance to Fairy attacks, Tera Fire also prevents Will-O-Wisp from hitting.

Items

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak makes Annihilape immune to being Salt Cured, making it a great check against Garganacl. It also gives peace of mind, removing potential flinches from Hydreigon's Dark Pulse or Special Defense drops from Flutter Mane's Shadow Ball.

  • Leftovers: Leftovers's residual recovery comes in handy if a different Pokemon is using Covert Cloak.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Jolly: Maximum Speed mainly helps Annihilape outspeed Gholdengo, Great Tusk, and Breloom. With Bulk Up and Rage Fist improving its offense, Annihilape can invest in HP over Attack.

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: More special bulk can make it much more difficult for special attackers such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult to revenge kill Annihilape.

  • 252 HP / 156 SpD / 100 Spe with Careful: This EV spread outspeeds Adamant Breloom and Cloyster while still giving Annihilape good special bulk.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Annihilape has enough Speed to surprise important threats with Choice Scarf, such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Meowscarada.

  • Shadow Claw versus Rage Fist: Shadow Claw is weak, but it's a reliable Ghost-type STAB move that can reliably OHKO Flutter Mane even when using minimum Attack investment. If you can manage to get Annihilape into a weak attack, though, Rage Fist has much more reward associated with it.

  • Ice Punch: Ice Punch deals massive damage to Garchomp and Dragonite, making them easier to pick off or pressuring them to Terastallize.

  • Final Gambit: If using maximum HP, Final Gambit can potentially OHKO major defensive threats if Annihilape is healthy, such as Garganacl and Corviknight.

Tera Types

  • Fighting: With a Fighting Tera type, Close Combat does outrageous damage, with Rotom-W in particular taking over 90% from it.

  • Ghost: A Ghost Tera type makes Shadow Claw OHKO Dragapult, as well as giving it a 56.3% chance of OHKOing 4 HP Gholdengo.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: This simple EV spread is best when not using Final Gambit to maximize offensive power.

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 Spe: While maximizing HP makes Annihilape a less reliable revenge killer, it can effectively sacrifice itself with Final Gambit to get surprise KOs on certain defensive foes, like Corviknight and Garganacl.

Abilities

  • Vital Spirit: The immunity to Spore gives Annihilape a good opportunity to switch into Breloom, and it need not worry about Yawn.

  • Defiant: While Intimidate is not particularly common, punishing that and Speed drops can lead to devastating surprise sweeps.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Setter
sets.description:
• Annihilape's good bulk and significant offensive presence makes it an easy to use Stealth Rock setter.

  • Rage Fist: Rage Fist is Annihilape’s strongest move; its power and coverage often lets Annihilape either defeat or significantly chip one of the opponent’s Pokemon on top of getting Stealth Rock up.

  • Taunt: Taunt gives Annihilape a strong matchup into bulky walls such as Hippowdon and opposing setup foes like Volcarona, while also making it easier to boost Rage Fist’s power.

  • Encore: Encore is an incredibly powerful move that can lock the opponent into an attacking move to boost Rage Fist's power. Alternatively, it can lock the opponent into a status move.

  • Final Gambit: Final Gambit has excellent synergy with Rage Fist; not only do they cover for each other's immunities, Final Gambit punishes foes that refuse to attack Annihilape to avoid boosting Rage Fist, allowing Annihilape to still take out a foe.

  • Curse: This is an excellent way for Annihilape to retire itself from the battle while putting significant pressure on the opponent to switch out and shutting down gimmicks such as Baton Pass.

  • Using speed controlling moves: A variety of lead Annihilapes run speed controlling moves. By using a Speed reducing move against a faster opponent rather than leading with Stealth Rock, Annihilape can scout the opponent's set, as well as providing support to its teammates. It also prevents foes from setting up on Annihilape. Speed reducing moves can help against those. Speed reducing moves are also better than Taunt and Encore at shutting down opposing Dragon Dance and Quiver Dance.

  • Rock Tomb: Rock Tomb is an excellent Speed reducing move for its ability to hit Dragonite, and threaten Volcarona and Iron Bundle. Its low accuracy should be noted as a risk, however.

  • Bulldoze: Bulldoze cannot hit Flying and Levitate Pokemon. In exchange, it is much more effective against Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Iron Treads, and Tinkaton.

Tera Types

  • Normal: Ghost-type attacks are incredibly common. Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and opposing Annihilape all struggle against an unexpected Tera Normal.

  • Steel: Tera Steel has excellent defensive synergy with Annihilape. It's noteworthy for halving the damage from common Dragon and Fairy-type moves.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 4 Atk / 4 Def / 108 SpD / 140 Spe with Jolly: This spread outspeeds critical Pokemon such as Dragonite, Adamant Baxcalibur, and Modest Gholdengo. The Special Defense investment lets Annihilape live Choice Specs Dragapult and Choice Scarf Gholdengo’s Shadow Ball with ease.

  • 172 HP / 4 Atk / 180 Def / 76 SpD / 76 Spe with Careful: This spread compromises some of Annihilape’s Speed to invest into more bulk. It still outspeeds Garchomp at -1 and certain sets of Dragonite, and lives Dragapult’s Choice Band Fairy Tera Blast on a roll.

Abilities

  • Vital Spirit: Vital Spirit adds to Annihilape’s reliability as a lead. Immunity to sleep moves from common Pokemon such as Breloom, Brute Bonnet, Dondozo, Hippowdon, and Skeledirge lets Annihilape thrive.

  • Defiant: Defiant is a strong option. While Intimidate Pokemon are far from common from the format, Defiant can take advantage of an opposing Annihilape’s speed control moves.

vgc2023.overview:
• Annihilape is a great Bulk Up user in Series 1 thanks to its unresisted STAB combination, good bulk, Rage Fist, and Defiant, which stops Attack drops from slowing down its clean up.

  • It can also utilize Choice Scarf to good effect, using Final Gambit as an immediate one-on-one trade option.

  • Rage Fist increases in power every time Annihilape is hit, making it a deadly move during longer games thanks to its good natural bulk.

  • Annihilape sports positive matchups versus much of the metagame, including, but not limited to, Maushold, Hydreigon, and Meowscarada. Additionally, its Defiant can be used to deter Intimidate Pokemon such as Arcanine and Gyarados, allowing strong ally physical attackers such as Garchomp and Gyarados to thrive.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
• To set up with Bulk Up safely, Annihilape enjoys dual screens and redirection support from Pokemon such as Grimmsnarl and Amoonguss.

  • Tera Blast is used to KO Steel-types Drain Punch does not hit super effectively, such as Gholdengo, without relying on Rage Fist being boosted.

  • The Fire Tera type gives Annihilape an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Talonflame and a key resistance to Fairy and neutrality to Ghost and Psychic, useful against opposing Annihilape, Meowscarada, and Armarouge. Furthermore, it lets Annihilape effectively combat Trick Room because, when played under dual screens, Annihilape can counter major Trick Room threats like Hatterene and Tera Fire Torkoal. Alternatively, picking Tera Water focuses on defensive advantages, primarily resistances to Steel- and Fire-type moves such as Gholdengo's Make it Rain and Torkoal's STAB moves.

  • Vital Spirit can be used instead of Defiant for mainly Amoonguss, but also other sleep move users like Yawn Sylveon and Hypnosis Gothitelle.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• This set is used commonly on Trick Room teams. Annihilape outspeeding most Pokemon, OHKOing them with Final Gambit, and being immune to Fake Out helps teammates like Hatterene and Armarouge set Trick Room, and fainting gives a free switch-in to a slow Trick Room beneficiary such as Tera Fire Torkoal. U-turn provides a switch-in without sacrificing Annihilape, and, while it doesn't OHKO, it hits common Pokemon such as Oranguru and Indeedee-F for large amounts of damage.

  • Shadow Claw is a consistent damage-dealing option that doesn't rely on foes to power it up. However, Rage Fist can still be utilized effectively thanks to Annihilape's bulk. Phantom Force avoids attacks and ignores protecting moves, giving Annihilape opportunities to deal unavoidable damage.

  • While not normally Terastallized, Annihilape can use Tera Ghost to remove its Fairy weakness and give a huge boost to its Ghost-type move, which becomes able to heavily dent much of the metagame.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: Annihilape's amazing bulk and the fantastic Rage Fist make it an amazing late-game wincon and wallbreaker. Bulk Up makes it harder for foes such as Great Tusk and Dragonite to break through it, as well as allowing it to break through defensive Pokemon like Buzzwole and Mega Scizor. Taunt prevents status, recovery, and set up from Pokemon like Skeledirge, Mega Scizor, and Landorus-T while also forcing foes to damage Annihilape, boosting the power of Rage Fist. Rage Fist lacks no switch-in once boosted up and allows Annihilape to demolish Pokemon that wouldn't mind it unboosted, such as Gholdengo and Mega Scizor. It also notably invalidates Unaware, enabling it to break through Pokemon like Clodsire and Skeledirge. Drain Punch provides Annihilape with some additional recovery, preventing it from being worn down quickly. Rest combined with Chesto Berry can be used over Taunt, as it provides Annihilape with a one-time way to recover HP and status, as well as being the premier way to heal from strong incoming hits, but it can be easily exploited if the foe is able to chip down Annihilape enough. Tera Water is the premier option, as it boosts Annihilape's defensive profile, giving it resists to moves like Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes and Gholdengo's Make It Rain. Fairy is another option that gives Annihilape nice resistances to moves like Mega Lopunny's Close Combat and an immunity to Draco Meteor or Dragon Darts from Dragapult. Tera Fire gives Annihilape an immunity to Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Skeledirge and Rotom-W while giving it a Fairy resistance as well, preventing the likes of Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant from revenge killing it. Notably, all of these types give Annihilape a Flying- and Ghost-type neutrality, preventing Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Dragapult, and Gholdengo from revenge killing it as easily. 28 Speed EVs help Annihilape outspeed Pokemon such as Mega Tyranitar, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W. The other EVs maximize its special bulk, letting it take hits comfortably from Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Dual screens setters like Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl let Annihilape tank hits more easily. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Heatran to wear down Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele is appreciated. Allies like Heatran and Tyranitar handle Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Tornadus-T, with Annihilape cleaning up once the aformentioned threats are removed.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Lead
sets.description: Annihilape carves a niche in being a Stealth Rock user that is immune to Rapid Spin from foes like Great Tusk and Iron Treads. Annihilape being a Defog deterrent due to Defiant, as well as its bulk and Final Gambit picking up easy KOs also strengthens this niche. Final Gambit lets Annihilape safely bring in a teammate while dealing massive damage due to its large HP stat. Taunt denies other entry hazards from being set up by Pokemon like Ting-Lu and preventing the use of Defog from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T on the switch. Defog can also activate Defiant, giving Annihilape way more offensive output for Rage Fist and making it easier to pick up a KO. Annihilape won't be Terastallizing often, but Tera Ghost can be used to boost the power of Rage Fist in scenarios where it is boosted, and it gives Annihilape neutralities to moves like Mega Diancie's Moonblast and Tornadus-T's Hurricane or Bleakwind Storm. Annihilape fits on hyper offense exclusively, so Pokemon that benefit from entry hazards being simultaneously denied and set up, such as Espathra and Dragonite, are good partners. Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Mega Diancie are very big problems for Annihilape, so partners like Gholdengo and Mega Scizor are very valuable. Final Gambit removing Pokemon like Great Tusk and Tornadus-T can also be a big help to teammates like Kingambit and Dragonite.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big new changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• While Clodsire is lacking in physical bulk compared to Dondozo and Skeledirge, it makes up for it in having a fantastic support movepool.

  • Yawn: Yawn is very effective at forcing switches, which is especially dangerous if Stealth Rock is set up.

  • Protect: In addition to benefiting from Leftovers, Protect pairs well with Yawn.

  • Low Kick: This prevents Clodsire from being totally walled by Tera Steel Hydreigon.

  • Amnesia: With Amnesia, Clodsire has a far better match-up against powerful special attacking foes such as Hydreigon and Iron Bundle.

  • Black Sludge versus Leftovers: Black Sludge may seem appealing, but it punishes Clodsire for Terastalliizing unless it becomes Tera Poison, so Leftovers is preferred unless Leftovers is already on something else.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Clodsire no longer has to worry about Earthquake or Fissure.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type allows Clodsire to take on powerful Dragon-type attacks, without the worry of Gholdengo dealing massive damage.

  • Poison: With Tera Poison, Clodsire not only becomes a better check to Grass- and Water-types such as Meowscarda and Rotom-W, but it can also safely run Black Sludge to punish users of Trick.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type will stop powerful Dragon-type attacks cold without making Clodsire weak to Earthquake, but it comes at the cost of compromising its ability to check Gholdengo.

  • Dark: Espathra's Stored Power is a big issue for Clodsire, so Tera Dark can flip the tables on it.

Abilities

  • Unaware: If you're planning to use Clodsire to its fullest defensive potential, Unaware is the best bet against setup foes.

  • Water Absorb: Water Absorb sacrifices overall defensive potential in exchange for being able to wall Rotom-W without needing to Terastallize. If setting up Stealth Rock is important, this can be worth it.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: Maximizing Special Defense is Clodsire's best hope for handling powerful special attackers such as Choice Specs Hydreigon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: Clodsire's Defense may be mediocre, but with maximum investment, it can pull stunts such as usually avoiding a 2HKO from Jolly Dragonite's Outrage with Leftovers.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: With huge HP and Special Defense stats, Clodsire makes use of Ice Scales to serve as a strong special wall, or it can instead function as a versatile support Pokemon that utilizes Prankster to cripple opposing Pokemon and deter setup. Toxic allows Clodsire to wear down opposing walls, while Toxic Spikes punishes switching and and cripples pivoting foes; Poison Jab is a final option to hit Noivern and still spread status. Spikes and Stealth Rock are both good options for additional entry hazards, with Spikes damage stacking with Toxic Spikes poison and Stealth Rock punishing Flying-types switching into Clodsire. Haze is another option that lets Clodsire stop threatening setup sweepers like Volcarona, though it should almost always be run on Prankster variants. Frail offensive teammates like Iron Bundle and Iron Valiant appreciate Clodsire's ability to soak up strong special attacks, and Clodsire appreciates them taking out foes it's too passive to handle on its own. Clodsire also has below average Defense, so it benefits from being paired with physically defensive teammates like Fur Coat Corviknight and Avalugg.

vgc2023.overview:
• Farigiraf is currently one of the bulkiest Trick Room setters in the meta. Its ability, Armor Tail, prevents its teammates from succumbing to priority moves, making it difficult to prevent Farigiraf from setting Trick Room.

  • Hariyama, Amoonguss, and Kingambit are good partners for Farigiraf. Hariyama and Farigiraf both benefit from each other, as Fake Out allows Farigiraf to more consistently get up Trick Room, which enables Hariyama, as it thrives inside of Trick Room and checks Farigiraf's common counters. Amoonguss can redirect moves targeted at Farigiraf and Spore anything inside Trick Room to take them out of the game. Kingambit benefits from the Snarl that Farigiraf struggles against and plays well in Trick Room.

  • Choice Band Meowscarada and Hydreigon are the biggest checks to Farigiraf, as both threaten to OHKO it. Amoonguss is another check, as it can Spore Farigiraf before it manages to get Trick Room up. It also struggles against Imprison from Indeedee, Gallade, and opposing Farigiraf.

sets.name: Bulky Trick Room
sets.description:
• Hyper Voice is a decently strong Normal-type STAB move for Farigiraf to spread chip damage that softens up opponents for its allies. Psyshock tackles common Psychic-weak Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Gengar, whereas Dazzling Gleam improves its matchup into common checks like Meowscarada and Hydreigon. Helping Hand allows Farigiraf to supplement a harder hitting teammate's damage output. Imprison is used on fast offensive teams that would otherwise struggle against opposing Trick Room teams.

  • Safety Goggles provides an immunity to Spore from Amoonguss and Breloom, who would otherwise prevent Trick Room from going up with it. Sitrus Berry gives Farigiraf longevity with recovery. Colbur Berry allows Farigiraf to consistently get Trick Room up in the face of Meowscarada and Hydreigon.

  • For other notable items, Mental Herb prevents fast Taunt users like Talonflame from interrupting Farigiraf's Trick Room. Life Orb or Throat Spray are good options to improve Farigiraf's already decent damage output. Rocky Helmet can also be used for an answer to unsuspecting Maushold.

  • 180 EVs in HP allow Farigiraf to survive maximum HP Annihilape Final Gambit, and the defensive investment allows it to always survive Tera Steel Choice Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain and Focus Sash Meowscarada Knock Off.

  • Tera Fairy is more of a defensive Tera type, giving it a resistance to all the types that Farigiraf was previously weak to while gaining STAB on Dazzling Gleam. Tera Normal adds damage onto Hyper Voice and removes its Dark weakness.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Supreme Overlord Kingambit is a terrifying revenge killer and sweeper. Dark / Steel is a great offensive typing that can hit Pokemon such as Skeledirge, Gholdengo, Dragapult, Garganacl, Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and Espathra super effectively as well as Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and Corviknight neutrally. Tera Flying completely reverses Kingambit's weaknesses and resistances and can catch Pokemon looking to KO Kingambit with Fighting- and Ground-type moves like Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant, off guard. Alternatively, Kingambit can opt for Tera Ghost to better counter Normal Tera Dragonite, as Earthquake becomes neutral against Kingambit and Extreme Speed is ineffective. Similarly, Tera Fairy can be chosen because Kingambit then resists Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon's Crunch, because with the exception of Tera Steel Roaring Moon, neither can OHKO Kingambit. Kingambit chooses to run 144 Speed EVs to reliably outspeed Corviknight and Swords Dance Iron Hands; the rest of its investment is in HP to maximize bulk.

Kingambit fits very well on hyper and bulky offense teams, as it works very well coming in after its teammates have fallen, such as Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, Breloom, and Dragonite. On hyper offense particularly, Grimmsnarl and Glimmora both work as great leads that set up screens and entry hazards, respectively. Kingambit checks opposing offensive Pokemon such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Meowscarada thanks to its defensive typing but it loses out against revenge killers such as Chien-Pao and Breloom and other threats like Calm Mind Iron Valiant, Iron Hands, Dodonzo, and Great Tusk; so, Kingambit appreciates defensive support from Great Tusk, Skeledirge, and Rotom-Wash and offensive support from Iron Valiant, Gholdengo and Dragapult.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Supreme Overlord makes Kingambit a threatening late-game sweeper and revenge killer.
  • 144 Speed EVs allow Kingambit to outspeed uninvested Alomomola, Skeledirge, and Corviknight.
  • Tera Flying allows Kingambit to survive otherwise super effective hits from Great Tusk, Iron Treads, non-Choice Band Koraidon, and Annihilape, allowing it to set up or dent these threats with a strong attack. Tera Ghost may be used to grant immunity to Fighting-type moves without a weakness to Ice-type attacks from Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao.
  • Teammates such as defensive Great Tusk, Skeledirge, Corviknight, and Toxapex are good checks to physical threats like Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Special walls such as Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire check fast special attackers like Miraidon and Iron Bundle while setting entry hazards for Kingambit. Setting entry hazards and spreading status is especially crucial, as most Kingambit checks have no viable recovery options.
  • Strong wallbreakers like Koraidon, offensive Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao support Kingambit late-game. Choice Scarf Koraidon is an excellent partner, as it outspeeds and threatens Kingambit's checks, and together they are able to overwhelm most of their shared checks.

sets.name: Swords Dance (Steel)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Kingambit sets itself apart from most other Dark-types with its bulk and typing, which make it a reasonable check against Gholdengo that lack Focus Blast.

  • Guillotine: This makes Kingambit far more difficult to wall with foes such as Dondozo.

  • Low Kick versus Brick Break: Low Kick is Kingambit's best option against other Kingambit, though Brick Break's destruction of dual screens makes it a great lead against Scream Tail and Grimmsnarl.

Tera Types

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type makes Kingambit even harder to wall and removes its irritating Ground weakness.

  • Flying: This Tera type covers Kingambit's issues with Fighting- and Ground-type attacks very well.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type and Tera Blast, Kingambit can deal serious damage to Iron Hands and Great Tusk, but it becomes vulnerable to Gholdengo.

Abilities

  • Supreme Overload: This is generally the more consistent ability since Intimidate foes are not very common.

  • Defiant: Defiant is still useful for punishing speed control options such as Rock Tomb, especially alongside Sucker Punch.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe: This simple spread maximizes bulk and power.

  • 108 HP / 252 Atk / 148 Spe: This EV spread has enough Speed to outspeed most Corviknight and Skeledirge, and it still has enough bulk to survive one unboosted Body Press from Corviknight. Since this is a fairly congested Speed range, feel free to move some Attack EVs to Speed.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe: Using maximum Speed might seem absurd on such a slow Pokemon, but outspeeding most Skeledirge, Corviknight, and opposing Kingambit can make this worth it.

Items

  • Black Glasses: While its boost to Dark-type attacks isn't as high as Life Orb's, Black Glasses is a better fit for Kingambit's bulk due to the lack of recoil.

  • Sitrus Berry: The burst of recovery helps Kingambit check Gholdengo better.

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest makes Kingambit a better check against Gholdengo and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Support
sets.description: This set is currently undergoing copyediting. If you would like to see the analysis in its current state, check it out here.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit is a dangerous wallbreaker, owing to great base stats and Adaptability. After using Swords Dance, Kingambit threatens the entire tier, including incredibly bulky physical walls such as Fluffy Corviknight and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster threats, such as Cinderance and Noivern, making it difficult to check offensively. Life Orb provides the highest damage boost to Kingambit's attacks; alternatively, Black Glasses provides a damage boost without digging into Kingambit's limited healthpool, while Leftovers allows Kingambit to reliably switch in on weaker attacks. Kingambit best fits on offense teams, which appreciate its massive damage output and can provide opportunities for it to switch in safely. Slow pivoting teammates, such as RegenVest Iron Treads and Corviknight, are recommended, as they can safely pivot Kingambit in and also clear entry hazards. 144 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight. Kingambit is incredibly threatened by Great Tusk, as it can easily live even boosted hits and threaten to OHKO back, so teammates like Florges and Noivern are appreciated.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Kingambit positions itself as a wallbreaker and late-game sweeper thanks to its signature ability in Supreme Overlord. Sucker Punch allows Kingambit to threaten faster opponents and would-be revenge killers such as Tornadus-T, Volcarona, and Mega Medicham. Tera Dark lets Kingambit strengthen its wallbreaking capabilities against bulkier teams. Tera Flying instead lets it play around potential revenge killers, putting them in checkmate situations by turning its Fighting and Ground weaknesses into resistances. 140 Speed EVs let Kingambit outspeed Skeledirge. Entry hazard leads such as Glimmora, Landorus-T, and Annihilape help Kingambit power through its checks by punishing switches. Kingambit is susceptible to faster Fighting-type Pokemon such as Great Tusk, Mega Lopunny, and Urshifu-R, as they will not succumb to a boosted Sucker Punch. Thus, wallbreakers like Dragapult, Dragonite, Espathra, and Iron Valiant that punish foes for using Fighting-type moves help form solid offensive cores; they can also pressure bulky Steel-types that check Kingambit, such as Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Heatran. In return, Kingambit helps check Psychic-, Ghost-, and Fairy-types, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Great Tusk is the best offensive Rapid Spin user and a fantastic wallbreaker thanks to its typing, bulk, and high-Base Power STAB attacks. Great Tusk takes on a plethora of physical attackers in the tier, including Kingambit, Garchomp, and Scizor while also threatening entry hazard setters such as Glimmora, Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Garganacl. Knock Off prevents Air Balloon Gholdengo from completely spinblocking Great Tusk, and it also removes items such as Rocky Helmet, Leftovers, and Heavy-Duty Boots from defensive Pokemon that commonly switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo, Corviknight, and Hatterene. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk take on Dragonite, Roaring Moon, and Garchomp more easily, though the lack of Close Combat leaves Great Tusk walled by Corviknight and Rotom-W. Maximum Speed investment paired with a Jolly nature ensures that Great Tusk is able to outspeed Rotom-W, non-Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Jolly Dragonite. Tera Fighting makes Great Tusk much better at taking on Water- and Ice-types such as Chien-Pao and Quaquaval while making Close Combat significantly harder to switch into; alternatively, Tera Steel lets Great Tusk flip its type weaknesses and take on Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and Tera Flying Roaring Moon. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Great Tusk from being worn down by Toxic Spikes and Spikes, letting it remove entry hazards consistently throughout a match; however, Leftovers provides Great Tusk with a form of recovery. Booster Energy is a niche option that provides Great Tusk with a one-time boost to its Attack, making it an immediately threatening wallbreaker without the use of Terastallization.

Great Tusk takes on Dark-type Pokemon such as Kingambit, and Ting-Lu, so Pokemon weak to Dark such as Dragapult, Gholdengo, Slowking, and Skeledirge appreciate Great Tusk; Slowking and Dragapult in particular are able to pivot in Great Tusk with Chilly Reception and U-turn, respectively. Great Tusk is also able to take on entry hazard setters such as Ting-Lu and Garchomp and remove entry hazards from the field, so Pokemon that can be overwhelmed by hazards such as Chien Pao, Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl appreciate Great Tusk's presence. Great Tusk struggles to take on faster special attackers such as Iron Valiant, Espathra, Dragapult, and Volcarona, so special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Toxapex are great partners. Great Tusk also has difficulty with physical walls such as Dondozo, Tera Water and Tera Fairy Garganacl, and Tera Fairy Skeledirge. Spikes support from Ting-Lu, Glimmora, and Garchomp wears down these checks into range of Great Tusk's attacks, especially when paired with Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Chien-Pao, Choice Specs Iron Valiant, Gholdengo, Iron Hands, and Breloom make for good partners by being able to overwhelm shared checks; Gholdengo is a noteworthy wallbreaker for also blocking opposing hazard removal, which wears down Great Tusk’s checks and limits Chien-Pao’s entry. Chien-Pao is difficult for Great Tusk to take on, forcing Great Tusk to Terastallize, so partners such as Quaquaval, Iron Hands, and Garganacl help take it on. Torkoal is also an excellent partner for Great Tusk, setting up the sun to activate Protosynthesis and weaken Water-type attacks, while supporting other wallbreakers that can pressure the aforementioned physical walls, such as Choice Band Roaring Moon, Scovillain, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description:
Great Tusk has a solid niche as a defensive Pokemon by virtue of its utility, movepool, bulk, and typing. It can adequately check Pokemon like Kingambit, Cinderace, and Iron Hands, threatening them with a strong Earthquake in return. Stealth Rock lets Great Tusk compress even more roles, chipping away at the opposition. If another Stealth Rock user is already on the team, however, Body Press can take advantage of its high Defense stat and better threaten the likes of Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon. Body Press also lets Great Tusk catch Rotom-W with greater chip damage than Knock Off does on the switch. Knock Off provides valuable item removal, getting rid of Leftovers from Pokemon like Dondozo, Corviknight, and Hatterene, as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from Volcarona and Dragonite. Additionally, Knock Off is Great Tusk's only initial way to hit Air Balloon Gholdengo, which can't OHKO this defensive set. Rapid Spin, besides clearing entry hazards, also allows Great Tusk to outspeed faster foes like Focus Sash Glimmora and Gholdengo. Tera Fighting gets rid of Great Tusk's Ground typing, giving it a better matchup against Pokemon like Chien-Pao while also strengthening Body Press if it is used. Alternatively, Tera Steel can give Great Tusk valuable resistances to Fairy, Grass, and Ice, turning the tables on Hatterene and Chien-Pao. Leftovers greatly increases Great Tusk's longevity; however, Rocky Helmet can be used to wear down Pokemon like Scizor and Cinderace over time.

After Great Tusk sets Stealth Rock, Corviknight effortlessly switches in and uses Defog to remove entry hazards, so Pokemon like Cinderace, Gholdengo, and Rotom-W that handle it are great partners. With no good way to hit Flying-types and Pokemon that use Tera Flying, Great Tusk can be set up on very quickly, most notably against the likes of Dragonite and Roaring Moon;even though the former dislikes Knock Off. Therefore, checks to these such as Dondozo and Corviknight are appreciated. A different Stealth Rock setter like Garganacl or Ting-Lu lets Great Tusk comfortably run Body Press without losing out on anything major. Ting-Lu also forms a potent entry hazard-stacking core with Great Tusk via Spikes. Further, it takes on the special attackers that Great Tusk struggles with, like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Volcarona. Great Tusk is forced out by wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Quaquaval, so teammates that can check them like Amoonguss and Toxapex are welcome. Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth appreciate the entry hazard removal that Great Tusk provides. Great Tusk's defensive qualities greatly help frail wallbreakers like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao, as these Pokemon need strong defensive Pokemon to fall back on very often.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
The combination of high Attack, powerful STAB moves, a decent movepool, and well-rounded physical bulk allows Great Tusk to function as a strong physical wallbreaker. It can support teams offensively with Knock Off and Rapid Spin as well as defensively through its ability to check Kingambit, Cinderace, and Choice Band Roaring Moon. Its dual STAB moves are able to OHKO or severely damage several key offensive Pokemon in the metagame such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Tera Normal Dragonite. Knock Off allows Great Tusk to remove Leftovers from walls such as Corviknight and Dondozo. It can also remove important items from more offensive Pokemon, such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Dragonite, Volcarona, and bulky pivot Roaring Moon, and it can provide coverage against Air Balloon Gholdengo, which otherwise checks this set. Ice Spinner hits Dragon-types that Headlong Rush isn't as strong against like bulky Garchomp and Dragonite. Alternatively, Rapid Spin can be run if the team is still in need of entry hazard removal. With Tera Fighting, Close Combat becomes much stronger, guaranteeing OHKOs against offensive Scizor sets. Tera Fighting also improves Great Tusk's matchups against Dondozo, Rotom-W, and opposing Great Tusk, and it removes its weakness to Ice, allowing it to better handle Chien-Pao. With Tera Steel, Great Tusk can better handle Ice- and Fairy-types such as Chien-Pao and Hatterene, and it can also shrug off attacks it normally can't, such as Meowscarada's Flower Trick and Dragapult's Draco Meteor. When running Great Tusk on sun teams, an alternate EV spread making Speed its highest stat can be considered due to Protosynthesis boosting Speed; this allows Great Tusk to outspeed otherwise faster Pokemon like Dragapult, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.

Rotom-W, Skeledirge, and Torkoal make for good teammates, since their status spreading can help weaken foes and help Great Tusk wallbreak more efficiently. Rotom-W is able to paralyze faster Pokemon such as Chien-Pao and boosted Quaquaval, allowing Great Tusk to outspeed them. Skeledirge is able to spread burn, capitalize on foes afflicted with status with a boosted Hex, and check Iron Valiant sets lacking Shadow Ball. Lastly, Torkoal is able to force switches thanks to Yawn, spread status with Lava Plume, and set up sun to make Great Tusk an even scarier wallbreaker. Great Tusk appreciates entry hazard support from the likes of Garganacl and Ting-Lu, since it can wallbreak more easily thanks to the chip damage they provide. Great Tusk is able to keep their hazards up in exchange while simultaneously removing hazards set by foes. Sweepers that are vulnerable to hazards like Iron Moth and Tera Flying Roaring Moon appreciate Great Tusk being able to remove hazards and beat walls such as Ting-Lu, allowing them to sweep more easily late-game. Lastly, other offensive Pokemon such as Kingambit and Dragonite make for good partners, since Great Tusk is able to weaken or cripple their common checks in Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description:
Bulk Up Great Tusk can act as both a defensive backbone and a potential late-game sweeper, able to set up in front of Pokemon such as Dragonite, Iron Treads, Cinderace, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and opposing Great Tusk. Knock Off provides item removal against defensive walls like Dondozo and Corviknight, as well as coverage against Air Balloon Gholdengo that would otherwise wall Great Tusk. Rapid Spin lets Great Tusk provide entry hazard removal for the team in games where it would not be able to win with Bulk Up, while allowing it to boost its Speed in games where it can sweep with Bulk Up. Body Press is another option that gives Great Tusk a way to more immediately hit Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu. Tera Water turns Great Tusk's Water and Ice weaknesses into resistances, allowing it to better take hits from Azumarill, Chien-Pao, Quaquaval, and Floatzel. On the other hand, Tera Steel lets Great Tusk take on Grass-type attacks such as Breloom's Bullet Seed and Meowscarada's Flower Trick, Flying-type attacks like Roaring Moon's Acrobatics, and if need be, Fairy-type attacks such as Iron Valiant's Moonblast.

Bulk Up Great Tusk appreciates specially defensive teammates like Toxapex and Garganacl that can help play around fast special attackers such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Dragapult. In return, Garganacl and Toxapex appreciate the presence of a Terastallized Great Tusk as they can get overwhelmed by Chien-Pao and Belly Drum Azumarill. Teammates such as Gholdengo, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult can help break through physically defensive Pokemon like Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Skeledirge that Bulk Up Great Tusk can struggle against. Gholdengo in particular is a great partner, as it can struggle against Cinderace and Dragonite, both of which Great Tusk covers.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• Tera Ground can turn Headlong Rush into a devastating STAB attack that can break through bulky targets Great Tusk normally wouldn’t, such as Scream Tail and Dondozo.
  • Tera Fighting lets Great Tusk crush Corviknight with Close Combat, which severely hurts defensive structures reliant on it. This opens up powerful teammates like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle.
  • Earthquake makes Great Tusk harder to revenge kill than Headlong Rush does, as it doesn’t drop its defenses.
  • Rapid Spin works well for teams weak to entry hazards. It's a great way to support powerful threats weak to Stealth Rock, like Chien-Pao, Chi-Yu, and Iron Bundle.
  • Knock Off provides fantastic item-removing support, and it especially cripples walls reliant on Leftovers like Scream Tail and Dondozo, allowing its team to more easily break past them.
  • Play Rough can be used to OHKO Koraidon without Terastallizing, as well as beating opposing Great Tusk. However, it has very little practical use outside of this.
  • Choice Scarf Great Tusk functions most effectively as a wallbreaker in the early- and mid-game, suited best for offensive structures that struggle with physical walls like the aforementioned Scream Tail and Dondozo. When building teams, remember Great Tusk must use Terastallization to actually break through said walls, so it may be hard for teammates to Terastallize.
  • Choice Band Great Tusk only functions well on Sticky Web teams, where the stronger and slower set appreciates Sticky Web dropping foes' Speed.
  • Koraidon is a great partner, setting up sun and activating Protosynthesis for Great Tusk. It further resists Water- and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, weakening the former. Koraidon also effectively baits in Skeledirge, which Great Tusk reliably threatens.
  • Miraidon is also a great partner, as it can threaten Flying-types, like Corviknight and the rarer Pelipper and Dragonite. This helps to make Great Tusk’s Headlong Rush much more spammable.
  • Gholdengo is also a good partner for Great Tusk, as it resists Ice-, Fairy-, and Grass-type moves aimed at Great Tusk, and it can threaten to KO Ice- and Fairy-types with super effective STAB Make It Rain. In addition, Gholdengo also blocks all hazard removal, helping to wear down walls for Great Tusk's team to eventually break through.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description:
• Great Tusk is the best offensive Stealth Rock or Rapid Spin user in the tier thanks to its solid typing and good physical bulk.
  • If Great Tusk is paired with Pokemon such as Corviknight, then Stealth Rock can be run instead of Rapid Spin. If paired with teammates that set Stealth Rock, then the best set would be Rapid Spin / Headlong Rush / Close Combat / Knock Off. Knock Off makes progress on Corviknight and covers the Air Balloon Gholdengo matchup.
  • Tera Ground lets Great Tusk deal incredible damage with Headlong Rush while also letting it survive Flutter Mane's Moonblast from full HP. Tera Steel flips the Fairy matchup and lets Great Tusk take on Ice- and Dragon-type attacks, but the additional weaknesses to Fighting and Ground make Great Tusk unable to take on Koraidon, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads easily.
  • Great Tusk can be used to take on entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Iron Treads one-on-one by forcing them out and removing hazards. Jolly is usually preferred to outspeed Gholdengo, Modest Chi-Yu, and Glimmora, but Adamant lets Tera Ground Headlong Rush OHKO Koraidon and specially defensive Annihilape after one layer of Spikes or Stealth Rock.
  • Great Tusk should be used aggressively to force out and keep entry hazards off the field against other setters, such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads, since Great Tusk is generally difficult to switch into. Great Tusk pairs well with Koraidon thanks to Orichalcum Pulse's sun, letting Great Tusk become an incredibly potent wallbreaker, and Great Tusk can clear entry hazards so that Koraidon can repeatedly come in. Miraidon also appreciates Great Tusk, as it forces out common checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Iron Treads. Great Tusk also appreciates Blissey being able to take on all of the special attackers that force Great Tusk out, such as Flutter Mane, Miraidon, and Iron Bundle.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description:
• Bulk Up allows Great Tusk to be a threatening sweeper. It can comfortably set up on common physical walls like Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and defensive Great Tusk.
  • The STAB combination of Headlong Rush and Close Combat hits most physical walls for at least neutral damage. Earthquake may be used as the Ground-type STAB move to avoid defensive drops, but it is a weaker move, and it can't secure important OHKOs and 2HKOs at +1 Attack against some physical walls such as Toxapex, Scream Tail, and Alomomola.
  • A Jolly nature is used to outspeed all viable unboosted Pokemon after one Rapid Spin. An Adamant nature makes Great Tusk stronger while still letting it outspeed unboosted Iron Bundle at +1 Speed, but it misses out on outspeeding maximum Speed Gholdengo and tying Jolly Great Tusk.
  • Terastallizing into the Ground typing boosts Headlong Rush and guarantees some additional OHKOs and 2HKOs on foes like Toxapex and Scream Tail. Additionally, getting rid of the Fighting typing lets Great Tusk survive Fairy-type attacks such as Dazzling Gleam from Miraidon and Moonblast from Flutter Mane without Life Orb or Choice Specs, and it facilitates taking Dazzling Gleam and Play Rough from Scream Tail and Alomomola.
  • Alternatively, using Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to Fairy-type attacks, Ice-type attacks from Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle, and Draco Meteor from Miraidon, allowing it to surprise them with a strong attack.
  • Koraidon is a solid partner because its sun activates Great Tusk's Protosynthesis, making its attacks even stronger. In return, Great Tusk can break through or strongly dent common Koraidon checks like Scream Tail, Alomomola, and Skeledirge, which allows Koraidon to clean more easily. Miraidon is also an excellent teammate, since Great Tusk can easily hard switch into its common checks and either threaten them with its attacks or set up on them.
  • Special attackers like Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle hugely threaten Great Tusk, so it is recommended to pair it with appropriate special walls like Blissey, Ting-Lu, Iron Treads, and Clodsire. Gothitelle is a less popular pick but it helps eliminate bulky checks like Dondozo and Pelliper, allowing Great Tusk to sweep more easily.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• Thanks to its solid physical bulk under sun and good defensive typing, Great Tusk acts as one of the best checks to Koraidon while also providing teams with entry hazard removal and a fantastic switch-in to other Ground-types in the tier such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Iron Treads.
  • Play Rough threatens a KO on Koraidon after entry hazard damage. Knock Off can be used to take on Air Balloon Gholdengo and wear down foes that want to switch into Great Tusk such as Corviknight and Annihilape, but it is generally outclassed by the sheer utility of Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock. The combination of Knock Off and Body Press can be used to pressure Corviknight switch-ins. A set of Earthquake, Stealth Rock, Knock Off, and Rapid Spin can also be used for similar utility.
  • Great Tusk can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to take on physical attackers such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, and Palafin in sun. However, be wary of Terastallizing against Koraidon that can still Terastallize themselves, as Choice Band Tera Fire Koraidon can take on Great Tusk one-on-one. Great Tusk can also Terastallize into the Ground typing or the Water typing, with both options removing its weakness to Fairy. The former also lets it fire off stronger Earthquakes as well, while the latter provides useful resistances to Fire moves from Koraidon as well as Ice- and Water-type moves, barring Freeze-Dry, from Iron Bundle.
  • Great Tusk fits on most teams as a bulky Stealth Rock setter and Koraidon check. Great Tusk can utilize Rocky Helmet to punish the use of U-turn, though this hurts its longevity, as it then loses Leftovers's passive recovery.
  • Great Tusk pairs well with defensive Scream Tail and Blissey, both of which can take on Iron Bundle while also providing Wish support for Great Tusk. Blissey can also take on Chi-Yu and Miraidon, while Scream Tail can take on Iron Valiant.
  • Great Tusk also pairs well with Gholdengo, as it appreciates Great Tusk forcing out Koraidon while preventing hazard removal in exchange. Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a good partner due to its ability to pressure faster special attackers that trouble Great Tusk such as Iron Bundle and Flutter Mane. Great Tusk also pairs well with Miraidon, as non-Heavy-Duty Boots Miraidon appreciates it removing entry hazards and taking on Clodsire, Iron Treads, and Ting-Lu. Finally, Koraidon is a good partner, as it can set up sun, pivot into Great Tusk, and force out most hazard removal options besides opposing defensive Great Tusk.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Fighting)
sets.description: These are sample sets before we work on new analyses. These will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets to get you started. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description: Rapid Spin, Knock Off, and great physical bulk make Great Tusk a fantastic utility spinner. It can check dangerous physical attackers such as Ceruledge, Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon and retaliate with its beefy Earthquake and Body Press. It matches up well against common entry hazard setters like Garganacl and Clodsire, and it threatens spinblockers with Knock Off; Knock Off also augments its teammates' entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Leftovers gives it much needed recovery—especially alongside Regenerator—but Heavy-Duty Boots prevents it from being overwhelmed by the entry hazards it must remove. Teammates such as Blissey and Slowking can cover opposing special attackers that target Great Tusk's lower Special Defense. In return, they appreciate Great Tusk dealing with physical attackers like opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Great Tusk is a dangerous wallbreaker thanks to its high-powered STAB moves and either Mold Breaker to bypass Fur Coat or Stakeout for the reliable power against non-Fur Coat targets. Knock Off has no immunities, unlike both STAB options, and removes key items like Leftovers from Corviknight. Ice Spinner breaks through defensive Dragonite and Garchomp with a clean OHKO. Fast specially offensive pivots like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, and Noivern can bring Great Tusk in safely to pressure their specially defensive switch-ins like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Blissey. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Hands are also good options, as they can switch into faster threats like Iron Bundle and Iron Moth, respectively, which force Great Tusk out. Dragonite and Ceruledge appreciate Great Tusk wallbreaking early-game by threatening Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Garganacl, which lets them clean up late-game more easily.

sets.name: Booster Energy (Speed)
sets.description:
• Bulk Up further boosts Great Tusk's naturally high Attack and Defense stats.
  • Booster Energy lets Great Tusk outspeed Meowscarada, Annihilape, and Corviknight.
  • Knock Off can be used to remove Choice items from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Magnezone.
  • Great Tusk’s EV spread allows for maximum Attack while still procuring the Speed boost from its Booster Energy. The HP investment increases Great Tusk's bulk and ensures its HP remains odd to have a better matchup against Leech Seed.
  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense stat, it's weak to bulky special attackers such as Weakness Policy or Air Balloon Gholdengo and Skeledirge.
  • Great Tusk is strong against Pokemon that it is able to outspeed due to Booster Energy and should use a damaging move against Choice Specs Iron Bundle, Meowscarada, and Chien Pao.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• With maximum Attack and Speed EVs and Choice Scarf, Great Tusk can outspeed and OHKO Meowscarada, non-Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao.

  • Head Smash is for Volcarona and Iron Jugulis.

  • Heavy Slam is for bulky Flutter Mane sets and Choice Specs Sylveon.

  • Alternatively, an EV spread of 164 Atk / 92 SpD / 252 Spe with Knock Off beats Modest Gholdengo, while some rolls, such as against Choice Specs Sylveon, become worse.

  • Due to Great Tusk's low Special Defense, it is weak to special attackers like Skeledirge, Speed Booster Energy Iron Bundle, Babiri Berry Sylveon, and Iron Valiant.

  • Since Great Tusk will be locked into an attacking move, opposing Annihilape can set up with Bulk Up and OHKO Great Tusk afterwards.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description: Great Tusk is an excellent Pokemon due to its amazing physical bulk, defensive typing, role compression, and movepool. It also has a very strong offensive presence and has utility moves in Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock to back it up. Headlong Rush is an amazing STAB move, letting Great Tusk force out Pokemon such as Heatran, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge very well. Earthquake can be used for a no-drawback STAB move, but the lack in power is certainly noticeable. Close Combat allows Great Tusk to annihilate Pokemon like Kingambit, and Ferrothorn, and it does a nice chunk to Rotom-W on the switch. Rapid Spin provides reliable entry hazard control, which is especially useful because Great Tusk forces out common Stealth Rock users like Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. It also lets Great Tusk outspeed foes like Iron Valiant, non-Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Tornadus-T. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Tornadus-T for good damage. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Great Tusk an entry hazard immunity and allows it to safely Rapid Spin, while Leftovers gives it passive recovery and lets it reliably check Pokemon like Kingambit and Garchomp. Booster Energy can be used to improve Great Tusk's already great offensive output, but since it is a one-time use item, it can be quite unreliable. Tera Water improves the matchup into Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Floatzel. Tera Ground removes Great Tusk's Fairy and Psychic weakness and bolsters its offensive output, letting it OHKO Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Volcarona. Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to the majority of its weaknesses, letting it KO Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko after luring them. Gholdengo and Kingambit make excellent partners for Great Tusk, as Gholdengo safely handles Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant while Kingambit can force out and Pursuit Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Dragapult. Great Tusk is commonly used as setup fodder against Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Volcarona, so partners like Clodsire and Dragonite can support it in that case. Entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn appreciate Rapid Spin support from Great Tusk, as it lets them keep entry hazards up while removing opposing ones, preventing the team from being worn down quickly. Stealth Rock-weak wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y also appreciate entry hazard removal from Great Tusk, as it lets them come in multiple times and poke holes in the opposition.

sets.name: Wish Support
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic.

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description: Scream Tail should very rarely be Terastillized, as its typing is needed to check foes like Gallade, Hawlucha, and Noivern and there are far better users of the mechanic. Additionally, its sole purpose is to set up dual screens and entry hazards, and changing to another type will not make a massive impact compared to another teammate.

sets.description: An Attack IV of 0-3 is needed to take minimum damage from Foul Play.

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Boomburst Scream Tail functions as a bulky utility option and a potentially powerful setup threat. With Boomburst, Scream Tail can topple many threats such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, making it far less passive than most walls. Calm Mind lets it serve as a bulky wincon, while Flamethrower deters Steel-types like Gholdengo from switching in and Stealth Rock lets it make progress against foes it cannot threaten like Ice Scales Clodsire. Scream Tail's great matchup into common Dark-, Fighting-, and Dragon-types makes it a great partner for offensive teammates that struggle with those foes, like Iron Bundle, Garchomp, and Iron Treads. Scream Tail struggles with Poison- and Fire-types such as Clodsire and Volcarona, as well as Steel-types if it does not run Flamethrower, so teammates such as Iron Bundle and Iron Treads are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Defensive Scream Tail serves as an answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Iron Hands and Dragonite. Encore locks Pokemon into moves that they do not want to be locked into, such as Volcarona with Quiver Dance or Morning Sun, Blissey into Soft-Boiled, and Avalugg into Recover. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be ran if the team needs entry hazard support. Fur Coat is the most common ability, but Regenerator allows it to better check opposing pivots like Iron Hands; alternatively, Prankster Encore can be used to deter opposing setup attempts. Scream Tail serves as a defensive answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types, so Pokemon such as Blissey and Kingambit are appreciated. It is unable to check several common physical attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit, so secondary physically defensive teammates like Regenerator Iron Hands are appreciated.

sets.name: Bulky Spore

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane functions as a great wallbreaker and revenge killer thanks to its already high Special Attack and Choice Specs, allowing it to break through unprepared teams with its dual unresisted STAB moves.
  • Mystical Fire 2HKOes specially defensive Iron Treads and serves as a way to hit Corviknight.
  • Psyshock is preferred in the last slot as a way to threaten specially defensive walls such as Blissey and Clodsire. Thunderbolt can be used to 2HKO Mirror Armor Corviknight and Toxapex.
  • Flutter Mane can Terastallize into the Fairy typing to further increase its damage output.
  • Flutter Mane pairs extremely well with Koraidon, as it can set up sun to further boost Flutter Mane's already impressive Speed. Koraidon can also pivot out via U-turn against Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Skeledirge, which Flutter Mane can threaten.
  • Physically defensive Corviknight is a great partner for Flutter Mane that can come in on attacks that target Flutter Mane's weaker physical defenses while also providing it safe entry via a slow U-turn.
  • This set appreciates entry hazard support from Great Tusk, which can also threaten Flutter Mane's checks such as Clodsire, Blissey, and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
• Flutter Mane can deal incredible damage to every Pokemon in the metagame due to its great coverage, notably 2HKOing most defensive foes.
  • Calm Mind allows Flutter Mane to OHKO Ting-Lu with Tera Fairy-boosted Moonblast, as well as defensive Great Tusk with Shadow Ball. Taunt can be used instead to stop bulky Pokemon like Blissey, Clodsire, Corviknight, and Toxapex from recovering health, giving Flutter Mane the advantage against bulkier teams.
  • Thunderbolt covers specially defensive Corviknight and Toxapex, whereas Mystical Fire hits Iron Treads.
  • Psyshock is a great option to strongly hit Blissey and Clodsire; Clodsire is an important target, as it otherwise walls Calm Mind + Life Orb variants due to Unaware.
  • Booster Energy can be used instead of Life Orb to boost Speed upon entry, but the drop off in damage is noticeable.
  • Tera Fairy allows Flutter Mane to dish out great levels of damage and lets it resist Sucker Punch from Chien-Pao. Tera Ghost allows Flutter Mane to 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Fire lets Flutter Mane resist Ice Shard from Chien-Pao and Ice Beam and Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle, while Tera Normal makes it immune to Shadow Ball from opposing Flutter Mane.
  • Entry hazard removal from the likes of Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads is appreciated, as residual damage can stack up quickly between entry hazards and Life Orb recoil.
  • Koraidon acts as a great teammate, setting sun for Flutter Mane's Protosynthesis to trigger.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Fairy)
sets.description:
Flutter Mane has a powerful dual STAB combination in Moonblast and Shadow Ball, as well as a plethora of coverage moves that allow it to choose its good matchups. Mystical Fire hits Steel-types such as Klefki and Iron Treads. Psyshock allows Flutter Mane to punish specially defensive switch-ins like Dragalge, Blissey, and Clodsire. Flutter Mane can run Power Gem to pressure Fire teams, OHKOing foes like Volcarona and Torkoal, and it also benefits from Protosynthesis allowing it to outspeed Scovillain under the sun. Additionally, Flutter Mane usually goes with either Thunderbolt or Energy Ball. Both are useful against Water teams, with the former helping against Toxapex and Pelipper while the latter deals with Gastrodon and Quagsire. Choice Specs further enhances Flutter Mane's wallbreaking power, allowing it to overwhelm foes such as Ting-Lu after some chip damage.

On Fairy teams, Flutter Mane is a menacing wallbreaker that excels at taking down slower foes such as Hydreigon, Skeledirge, and Corviknight. When paired with Iron Valiant, Flutter Mane forms an offensive core that's able to alternate between Fairy-, Ghost-, and Fighting-type STAB to take down a wide range of enemies. Flutter Mane can handle Psychic-type foes such as Espathra and Hatterene, while Iron Valiant takes care of Steel-types like Kingambit and Iron Treads. Flutter Mane can fall back on either Hatterene or Tinkaton when faced with an unfavorable matchup. Both of these Pokemon provide dependable defensive options and some type of entry hazard control, but Hatterene is particularly useful due to it breaking down walls like Dondozo and Clodsire. Flutter Mane also pairs well with setup sweepers like Belly Drum Azumarill and Swords Dance Mimikyu, as it is able to poke holes in the opponent's team, allowing them to clean late-game. In return, Azumarill can take care of priority users, such as Ceruledge and Chien-Pao. In terms of support options, Flutter Mane can rely on Fairy's Prankster users, Klefki and Grimmsnarl, to set up dual screens, therefore allowing it to withstand hits such as Mimikyu's Shadow Sneak and Gholdengo's Make It Rain. Grimmsnarl can then bring in Flutter Mane relatively safely thanks to Parting Shot. Klefki's Spikes and Tinkaton's Stealth Rocks also support Flutter Mane in breaking its checks such as Iron Hands and Ting Lu. Entry hazard stacking proves particularly useful against less bulky teams, as it highly limits their capacity to scout Flutter Mane without having to sacrifice a member in the process.
