sets.name: Specs Flutter
sets.description: This set is currently undergoing copyediting. If you would like to see the analysis in its current state, check it out here.

sets.name: Normalize
sets.description: Normalize Flutter-Mane is a dangerous setup sweeper that requires specific counterplay to deal with. Entrainment + Normalize prevents foes from damaging Flutter Mane, with its Fairy typing giving it an immunity to the common Draco Plate Judgment. Quiver Dance increases damage output and allows Flutter Mane to outspeed and nullify would-be faster threats like Zacian-C. Taunt prevents defensive checks from PP stalling Flutter Mane and denies Glare; alternatively, Strength Sap provides Flutter Mane with longevity, allowing it to repeatedly switch into passive Pokemon. Pixie Plate lets Flutter Mane hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Arceus-Dark super effectively, whereas Spooky Plate lets it hit Imposter users and opposing Ghost-types harder. A Modest nature provides a power boost, while Timid can be used to outspeed positive natured Arceus formes to use Entrainment first. Flutter Mane struggles against bulky Magic Bounce and Good as Gold users, so strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Zacian-C and Choice Specs Miraidon are good partners. Even with Normalize, Flutter Mane can still be statused by moves like Glare and Will-O-Wisp, so a Heal Bell user can be helpful. Flutter Mane also has poor physical bulk, so slow defensive pivots like Ting-Lu and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra are appreciated to bring Flutter Mane in safely while also providing Knock Off support to remove Ability Shield.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Thunder is for Azumarill, Corviknight, and some Dondozo.
  • Psyshock is for Iron Moth and Clodsire.
  • Power Gem is for Volcarona.
  • Mystical Fire helps against Abomasnow and Choice Specs Magnezone.
  • Alternatively, an EV spread of 160 Def / 172 SpA / 176 Spe with a Timid nature noth outspeeds and survives Sucker Punch from Adamant Choice Band Meowscarada. The remaining EVs are put in SpA.
  • Due to its low Defense, Flutter Mane is weak against bulky Pokemon that can live a hit and OHKO back such as Iron Treads, Slaking, and Donphan.

sets.name: All-Out-Attacker
sets.description:
Protective Pads is an option that lets Slither Wing more freely attack Talonflame, although Choice Band sets can still potentially OHKO it with Wild Charge while risking one Flame Body burn.

Tera Bug powers up Slither Wing's First Impression and U-turn to maximize its revenge killing potential and chip damage. Tera Ghost is an option to spinblock and check Lucario, Maushold, and opposing Slither Wing. Tera Fighting powers up Close Combat to maximize damage versus Quagsire and Hippowdon.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Bug powers up Slither Wing's First Impression and U-turn damage, making it harder to pivot around and letting it revenge kill faster Pokemon such as full HP Floatzel.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description:
Morning Sun lets Slither Wing use its typing more effectively to check Pokemon such as opposing Slither Wing and Tsareena. Stun Spore instead lets Slither Wing cripple switch-ins like Salamence and Talonflame to create openings for teammates such as Choice Specs Toxtricity.

Tera Ghost lets Slither Wing spinblock and check Maushold and Lucario. Tera Bug is an alternative that improves its ability to revenge kill Pokemon.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon is likely to be relevant in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing’s massive Attack stat combined with STAB U-turn and First Impression allow it to be a great wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Earthquake is an option to bash Skeledirge whereas Flare Blitz is better into Corviknight and bulky Fighting resistant foes such as Scream Tail on non-Tinted Lens sets. Tinted Lens is useful for revenge killing Dragonite, and Volcarona with First Impression after minimal chip, Sword of Ruin provides the most power against neutral targets, and Oricalchum Pulse is recommended for Flare Blitz variants. Special wallbreaker partners such as Noivern and Gengar break physical walls that trouble Slither Wing and appreciate Slither Wings's ability to break their checks in return. Slither Wing loves being partnered with bulky pivots such as Chilly Reception Slowking, Corviknight, and Desolate Land Volcarona to get it in safely against the opposing team and start punching holes in defensive cores. Slither Wing tends to invite in Fire-types onto the field, so fire resistant teammates such as Garchomp and Garganacl are appreciated.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Good natural bulk, useful defensive typing, and an excellent support movepool make Slither Wing a good mixed defense pivot that repeatedly pivots and most notably switches into Ground-types like Great Tusk. Regenerator makes the most of its pivoting ability, but Unaware is an option for deterring setup. Will-O-Wisp allows it to punish switch-ins like Garchomp with a burn. Its massive Attack allows it to use STAB U-turn to maintain momentum while bringing in more offensive teammates like Chi-Yu and Greninja. Even with investment, Slither Wing struggles to check certain physical attackers like Ceruledge and Dragonite, so Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight make good teammates. Slither Wing also has difficulty against Fairy- and Flying-types like Scream Tail and Noivern, so it appreciates teammates like Iron Moth and Garganacl that are able to handle them.

sets.name: Hazards Lead
sets.description: Tera Ghost is used to potentially spinblock while utilizing Sandy Shocks's solid matchup versus Defog users, such as Talonflame, to help keep its entry hazards up.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Tera Ice lets Sandy Shocks break through Kilowattrel and Hippowdon with Tera Blast, which otherwise wall it. Tera Grass instead lets it OHKO Gastrodon with Tera Blast.

Tera Ground should be used when running entry hazards to put as much pressure on Quagsire and Gastrodon as possible, but Sandy Shocks is not a high-value Terastillization user in this case.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Tera Ice lets Sandy Shocks break through Kilowattrel and Hippowdon with Tera Blast, which otherwise wall it. Tera Grass instead lets it OHKO Gastrodon with Tera Blast.

Sandy Shocks can alternatively run Power Gem to break Kilowattrel while running Tera Ground to let it 2HKO Gastrodon without giving up its Ground typing.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Tera Ground lets Sandy Shocks apply as much pressure as it can against Quagsire and weakened Gastrodon with Earth Power, making it harder for them to take advantage of its Choice lock.

sets.name: Choice Specs (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
This new Paradox Pokemon might have a niche in Battle Stadium Singles Series 2, though their viability is uncertain. While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets that may be viable. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description: An Attack IV of 0-1 is needed to take minimum damage from Foul Play.

sets.name: Hazards Setter
sets.description: An Attack IV of 0-1 is needed to take minimum damage from Foul Play.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Noiver, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Noivern and Gengar, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and Gengar can fire off Terrain-boosted Thunderbolts. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
• A decent defensive typing allows Iron Treads to act as a check to Miraidon and Flutter Mane, and use the opportunity to remove or set entry hazards.
  • Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Ting-Lu and Corviknight, while Volt Switch keeps momentum for your team.
  • 16 IVs in Defense mean that Iron Treads will receive a Special Defense boost in Electric Terrain, helping with switching into Miraidon.
  • Iron Treads can use Tera Fairy to remove its weaknesses to Fighting and Fire, which can be helpful versus Koraidon and Chien-Pao, and with taking coverage from Miraidon and Flutter Mane. However, it loses its immunity to Electric and resistances to Dragon and Fairy. Iron Treads can alternatively use Tera Ground for an extra boost to Earthquake, but it suffers from similar demerits as Tera Fairy.
  • Since both Miraidon and Flutter Mane have Fire-type coverage options, Iron Treads appreciates being paired with Pokemon such as Ting-Lu that can handle those attacks. Choice Scarf Koraidon and Booster Energy Flutter Mane are also good teammates, as they can revenge kill Miraidon and Flutter Mane while benefitting from Iron Treads removing entry hazards.
  • Skeledirge's ability to check Koraidon and Iron Valiant also makes it a great partner for Iron Treads. Teammates that can switch into Great Tusk such as Dondozo and Alomomola also pair well, with Alomomola even providing Wish support to increase Iron Treads's longevity.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Assault Vest allows Iron Treads to utilize an offensive spread while still letting it be a fairly safe option against Miraidon and Flutter Mane.
  • Iron Head allows Iron Treads to beat Tera Fairy Miraidon.
  • Knock Off can remove crucial items from foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Volt Switch is useful for grabbing momentum on non-Ground-type foes that switch in on Iron Treads like Corviknight, Koraidon, Dondozo, and Pelipper.
  • A Jolly nature gives Iron Treads a Speed boost from Quark Drive, which is often crucial to be able to beat Choice Specs Miraidon one-on-one, and lets it pick off foes that would normally outspeed it without Electric Terrain.
  • Ground is the preferred Tera type to boost the power of Earthquake while weakening incoming Fire- and Fighting-type attacks; alternatively, other Tera types can provide defensive utility but not any offensive boost.
  • This set works best on offensive teams where it is paired up with teammates that are weak to Fairy-type moves, such as Miraidon, Koraidon, Great Tusk, and Chien-Pao. Iron Treads allows these Pokémon to be played more freely because it can reliably deal with Flutter Mane and opposing Miraidon while applying offensive pressure itself.
  • Flutter Mane is another great teammate because Iron Treads lures Corviknight and weakens it with Knock Off or Volt Switch, this gives Flutter Mane an easier time to break through enemy teams.

sets.name: Utility (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Offensive Support

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Gholdengo and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Dragonite, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Noivern and Cinderace.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description:
• Freeze-Dry and Hydro Pump make Iron Bundle incredibly threatening with perfect coverage.
  • Taunt can be used to stop recovery and status attempts from walls like Corviknight, while Flip Turn can gain momentum. Encore is effective at PP stalling recovery attempts from Pokemon while also locking Pokemon into suboptimal moves like Stealth Rock to take advantage of.
  • Tera Ice boosts Freeze-Dry's and Ice Beam's power to high levels and also removes the neutrality to Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle, making a potential mirror match safer.
  • Tera Water Iron Bundle has immense power on Hydro Pump; Tera Water also removes its Fighting-type weakness and Fire-type neutrality, which helps against Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Koraidon trying to revenge kill it.
  • Iron Bundle has to use its high Speed to force out frail Pokemon or force defensive Terastallization, both of which it can take advantage of.
  • Getting Iron Bundle safe switch-ins on defensive Pokemon that are threatened by Hydro Pump is the best way to use its offensive capabilities, allowing for defensive answers to be Taunted or pivoted on to wear down opposing teams.
  • Pelipper and Miraidon are strong teammates for Iron Bundle, providing rain and Electric Terrain support to power it up.
  • Entry hazard setters are also very strong, since Iron Bundle appreciates checks like Corviknight and Annihilape being worn down. It also can use Taunt to stop Defog Corviknight and pressure the premier spinners in Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• The combination of Hydro Pump and Freeze-Dry gives Iron Bundle an unresisted STAB combination, making it extremely threatening with Choice Specs.
  • Flip Turn allows Iron Bundle to pivot in order to gain momentum, while Ice Beam OHKOes Koraidon and uninvested Miraidon.
  • Tera Ice allows Iron Bundle to further boost its Ice-type moves and resist Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle and Ditto. Tera Water is a good option on teams with rain support in order to let it 2HKO Heavy-Duty Boots Blissey in rain after slight chip.
  • Choice Specs allows Iron Bundle to 2HKO walls such as Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Scream Tail with Hydro Pump as well as Toxapex with Freeze-Dry.
  • Miraidon is a great teammate, as it can lure in Pokemon weak to Hydro Pump such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads and pivot into Iron Bundle using U-turn. It also sets Electric Terrain, giving Iron Bundle a Speed boost upon entry.
  • Entry hazard removal options such as Corviknight, Iron Treads, and defensive Great Tusk are great teammates, as Iron Bundle can get worn down pretty quickly from repeatedly switching into Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description: • The given EV spread, nature and Assault Vest allow Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Overheat from Chi-Yu and OHKO it in return with Hydro Pump while retaining enough speed to move before Meowscarada. Incidentally, the spread also allows Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth is a powerful special attacker that also provides good defensive utility thanks to Desolate Land and Morning Sun. Its near-unique offensive typing lets it threaten common walls like Corviknight and Scream Tail, especially when boosted by sun. U-turn can be used to maintain momentum against predicted switch-ins like Garchomp and Garganacl, while Toxic Spikes punishes switch-ins with status. Iron Moth complements Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their vulnerability to Primordial Sea Greninja. Pokemon like Kingambit and Dragonite appreciate Iron Moth taking advantage of their Steel-type checks like Corviknight.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Specially defensive Iron Moth uses its solid bulk, good defensive typing, and sun-boosted Morning Sun to consistently check foes like Volcarona and some Gholdengo variants. It's not entirely passive either, as the boosts from Fiery Dance under sun allow it to eventually overwhelm passive foes like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Florges. U-turn lets it gain momentum by pivoting out safely, and Toxic Spikes punishes grounded foes like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Iron Hands. Due to its devastating Ground weakness, Ground-immune Pokemon like Corviknight and Dragonite make good pairings with it. Iron Moth works well with wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Iron Bundle, as they appreciate being given free entry to threaten its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Iron Moth is a great complement to special walls like Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their type weaknesses.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Sweeper
sets.description:
• With good bulk, an immunity to burn, and just enough Speed to work, Baxcalibur is a powerful sweeper.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear KOes Breloom and Mimikyu through Focus Sash and Disguise respectively.

  • Glaive Rush: While Glaive Rush is valuable for late-game sweeping, it does make Baxcalibur very vulnerable to bulky OHKO move users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Ice Shard: Ice Shard means Baxcalibur will have a difficult time breaking past bulky Steel-types early-game, but it makes it an effective cleaner otherwise.

Other Options

  • Swords Dance: Dragon Dance is the more reliable option for sweeping due to Baxcalibur's Speed, but Swords Dance can be paired with Ice Shard and an Adamant nature to OHKO fast, frail foes such as Booster Energy Flutter Mane.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: This makes Glaive Rush deal obscene damage and removes weaknesses to Mach Punch and Bullet Punch.

  • Electric: When paired with Tera Blast, this is Life Orb Baxcalibur's best shot at dealing damage to Dondozo switch-ins. The paralysis immunity also helps Baxcalibur set up against Chansey with less risk.

  • Ice: Tera Ice works great with Swords Dance and Ice Shard, making Baxcalibur easier to clean teams with.

  • Steel: With a Tera type of Steel, Baxcalibur can set up on Mimikyu and Dragon-type attacks.

Items

  • Life Orb: This helps Baxcalibur sweep reliably and ensures Icicle Spear OHKOes Breloom through Focus Sash.

  • Loaded Dice: With a guaranteed 4 hits from Icicle Spear, Baxcalibur is able to always OHKO offensive Mimikyu after Dragon Dance.

  • Focus Sash: Focus Sash may seem like a waste with Baxcalibur's bulk, but it provides new set up opportunities and eases match-ups against other Dragon-types.

sets.name: All-Out Attacker
sets.description:
• Baxcalibur's bulk and the wonderful Ice Shard means it doesn't need to set-up to become a powerful threat.

  • Icicle Spear: Icicle Spear is recommended despite its inconsistent damage, as it deals damage through Mimikyu's disguise and potentially KOes Focus Sash users like Breloom and Meowscarada.

  • Glaive Rush: Glaive Rush makes Baxcalibur very vulnerable to getting KOed the next turn, but it is still the least risky Dragon-type STAB move. Remember that Ice Shard will remove Glaive Rush's negative effects as well.

Tera Types

  • Ground: A Ground Tera type gives Baxcalibur a reliable STAB move in Earthquake, resistance to Stealth Rock, and removes a ton of weaknesses, all at the cost of losing to Water-types such as Rotom-W and Iron Bundle.

  • Electric: With Tera Electric, Baxcalibur's Tera Blast deals massive damage to Corviknight that lack a set up move, Azumarill, does good chip damage to Dondozo, and gains a valuable resistance to Gholdengo's Make It Rain.

  • Ice: Boosting the power of Ice Shard gives Choice Band Baxcalibur new revenge kill chances, and makes wall breaking with Icicle Spear easier.

Items

  • Assault Vest: Baxcalibur's bulk makes it an excellent user of Assault Vest, making it particularly effective against Rotom formes and Iron Bundle.

  • Choice Band: With Choice Band, Baxcalibur becomes an immediate threat, threatening to 2HKO physical walls such as Dondozo.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This simple EV spread maximizes Baxcalibur's bulk and power.

  • 116 HP / 252 Atk / 140 Spe with Jolly: The Speed investment here outspeeds Modest Gholdengo and Adamant Dragonite.

  • 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with Jolly: If using Choice Band, winning Speed ties against Great Tusk and opposing Baxcalibur makes maximum Speed much more appealing.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Baxcalibur is a powerful setup sweeper thanks to its great stats and fantastic STAB coverage. Dragon Dance patches up its below-average Speed to facilitate a late-game sweep, while Swords Dance is better suited for wallbreaking and cleaning up with Ice Shard. Earthquake is the preferred move on Dragon Dance sets to hit Iron Hands and Garganacl. Heavy-Duty Boots preserves Baxcalibur's bulk to make setup easier. Baxcalibur fits best on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to both wallbreak and sweep. It pairs well with other strong wallbreakers such as Orichalcum Pulse Ceruledge, as they can overwhelm their shared checks. Special attackers such as Iron Bundle and Chi-Yu are good partners, as they threaten out the physically defensive Pokemon that can give Baxcalibur trouble.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Baxcalibur is a threatening attacker that overwhelms common walls such as Hippowdon and Great Tusk with its powerful STAB moves, especially with Ice's vaunted offensive coverage. Ice Shard threatens many offensive Pokemon like Noivern, Sandy Shocks, and Great Tusk. Earthquake threatens the Steel- and Fire-types that resist Baxcalibur’s STAB moves such as Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Choice Band Baxcalibur fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to force damage on walls for its teammates. Its weakness to Stealth Rock makes entry hazard removers like U-turn Corviknight, Iron Treads, and Great Tusk great teammates. Other physical attackers such as Ceruledge are good partners, as they can overload common physically defensive Pokemon such as Skeledirge. Special attackers such as Iron Valiant and Iron Bundle also make good partners, as they can threaten the physically defensive Pokemon that Baxcalibur has trouble breaking.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gholdengo utilizes its high Special Attack and its great offensive typing to become a fast revenge killer. Gholdengo can effectively hit offensive threats such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Espathra with its STAB moves. Trick allows Gholdengo to cripple defensive Pokemon such as Dodonzo, Corviknight, and Clodsire. Its typing also allows it to switch into foes such as Iron Valiant and Iron Hands in a pinch, as it either resists or is immune to most of their attacks. Focus Blast is ideal for Gholdengo to hit Kingambit and other foes such as a weakened Ting-Lu, but Nasty Plot can be run instead to take advantage of stopping defensive Pokemon with Trick and having a free turn to set up and do a great amount of damage. Recover can also be run, taking a more defensive approach to give Gholdengo a free turn to heal. Gholdengo prefers Fighting as a Tera type, as it removes its prior weaknesses, meaning it is not threatened by Chien-Pao's and Kingambit's Sucker Punch, or Skeledirge's Torch Song. It also boosts the power of Focus Blast, reliably removing the latter. To counter different foes, Gholdengo can instead opt for Tera Flying to have better ground against Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

Teammates such as Kingambit and Iron Valiant appreciate Gholdengo's offensive pressure, as it can help against shared checks such as Great Tusk and Amoonguss. With this role, Gholdengo prefers to have a clean switch after a teammate has fainted in order to pressure the opponent. Similarly, entry hazard setters such as Garchomp, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu appreciate Gholdengo for its Good as Gold ability and its Ghost typing, preventing all forms of hazard removal excluding Court Change. Gholdengo is mainly vulnerable to priority moves such as Kingambit's and Chien-Pao's Sucker Punch. Dragonite also presents an issue for it with Multiscale in conjunction with Earthquake, not to mention it can set up twice in front of Gholdengo. This can be avoided with a carefully timed Trick or help from defensive Great Tusk and Skeledirge. Similarly, depending on its Choice lock, Roaring Moon and Cinderace can take advantage of Gholdengo with Crunch and Sucker Punch, respectively. As a result of this, Garchomp and Garganacl pair well with Gholdengo, acting as a defensive backbone with type advantage and great bulk. Iron Valiant can be a great revenge killer against these threats with great Speed and coverage.

sets.name: Air Balloon
sets.description:
Thanks to its great typing and Good as Gold, Gholdengo is a setup sweeper that's notably difficult to deal with. Having an additional Ground immunity with Air Balloon further improves Gholdengo's already great typing, letting it switch in on Pokemon that otherwise threaten it, such as Garchomp and Iron Treads. This is especially useful against the latter, as Air Balloon strengthens Gholdengo's ability to block entry hazard removal. Maximum Speed investment is for outspeeding Dragonite and uninvested Great Tusk. 252 Special Attack EVs and Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo's STAB moves very threatening against neutral foes. Fighting and Dark Tera types give Gholdengo the option to Terastallize defensively; notably, Tera Fighting lessens the impact of moves like Crunch from Chien-Pao and Roaring Moon. Tera Dark is useful in a pinch to resist attacks such as Shadow Ball from Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo.

Entry hazard setters like Great Tusk and Glimmora are the most profitable teammates for Gholdengo, as its ability and typing ensure that their entry hazards stay around as long as Gholdengo does. Hyper offense staples such as Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant benefit greatly from the constant presence of entry hazards to break down bulkier cores; in return, Gholdengo gets teammates that synergize with its role as a wallbreaker, applying heavy pressure throughout a game to Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Rotom-W. Offensive Pokemon that outspeed and OHKO Gholdengo, such as Cinderace, Chien-Pao, Roaring Moon, and Knock Off variants of Great Tusk, threaten to completely shut down Gholdengo; defensive teammates like Garganacl, Dondozo and Skeledirge can help mitigate some of these weaknesses.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Choice Scarf Gholdengo outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, can use Trick to weaken defensive teams, and also blocks Defog and Rapid Spin to keep pressure on defensive Pokemon with entry hazards.
  • Focus Blast deals more damage to Ting-Lu, Chi-Yu, and Iron Treads, while Nasty Plot and Recover can be used after Gholdengo's Choice Scarf has been removed via Trick to turn it into a setup sweeper or give it longevity, respectively.
  • Tera Fighting powers up Focus Blast, which allows Gholdengo to potentially 2HKO Ting-Lu. Alternatively, Gholdengo can use Tera Steel on sets not using Focus Blast to boost Make It Rain and remove its weaknesses to Flutter Mane's and Chien-Pao's STAB moves.
  • Gholdengo should almost always be switched in if Corviknight is on the field and be used sparingly against Great Tusk and Iron Treads if a Rapid Spin is predicted, but this is risky due to its Earthquake weakness.
  • Spikes setters like Ting-Lu and Clodsire on balance teams as well as Froslass on hyper offense teams appreciate Gholdengo keeping up Spikes and it acting as a revenge killer for their respective archetypes.
  • Pokemon like Calm Mind Miraidon, Calm Mind Flutter Mane, and Swords Dance Chien-Pao also benefit from Gholdengo using Trick on defensive Pokemon, forcing them to either heal or be locked into an unfavorable attack while they set up. Gholdengo can also clean up weakened teams if these Pokemon are used to wallbreak first.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot + Recover Gholdengo is the best option for preventing entry hazard removal in the tier.
  • Tera Steel bolsters Make It Rain's power, allowing Gholdengo to overwhelm threats such as Koraidon, defensive Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and bulky Tera Fairy Miraidon after a Nasty Plot boost while removing its Ghost typing.
  • Tera Normal blocks incoming Ghost-type attacks from the likes of Flutter Mane, Choice Scarf Houndstone, and opposing Gholdengo.
  • Air Balloon provides a temporary measure against Ground-type attacks from Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, allowing Gholdengo to sometimes switch into them.
  • Gholdengo best fits on hyper offense and balance teams that aim to preserve their own entry hazards for as long as possible.
  • Frail leads such as Froslass and Masquerain appreciate their entry hazards staying intact against Great Tusk, Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Glimmora.
  • Glimmora and Ting-Lu make for good teammates on balance teams in particular, as they provide similar entry hazard support while having sufficient power and bulk to punish threats.
  • Wallbreakers such as Miraidon, Koraidon, and Chi-Yu appreciate multiple entry hazards to further overwhelm the opposition with their tremendous attacks and power.

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
With Paradox Pokemon being introduced, Series 2 is bringing big changes to Battle Stadium Singles! This is a modified Series 1 analysis that takes Paradox Pokemon into account. We will update this overview and analysis again once the metagame settles more. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• With Trick and an immunity to status moves, Gholdengo is a dangerous Choice item attacker for offensive and stall teams alike!

  • Thunderbolt: This 2HKOes Dondozo and deals serious damage to Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Dazzling Gleam Dazzling Gleam deals massive damage to Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon.

  • Nasty Plot: This can be used to give Gholdengo more bite against defensive, slower teams after using Trick.

  • Focus Blast: Though it's accuracy can be an issue, Focus Blast is the best way around Kingambit.

  • Neutral Nature and Nature Mints: Use a neutral nature Gholdengo that has a Timid or Modest Mint used on it. This way, Gholdengo can eat any Berry without being confused after Trick.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Gholdengo gains an extremely useful immunity to Ground, which is especially useful on Choice Specs sets and against users of Fissure such as Dondozo.

  • Ghost: The extra damage from Shadow Ball can make Gholdengo a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Gholdengo a far better chance of defeating Kingambit.

  • Water: In addition to giving Gholdengo a valuable resistance to Fire, this makes Gholdengo deal much more damage to Volcarona and common Tera Fire users such as Dragapult.

  • Steel: Make It Rain becomes very powerful with a Tera boost, at the cost of making Gholdengo vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Normal: A Normal Tera type gives Gholdengo the edge against opposing Ghost-types, at the cost of becoming very vulnerable to Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With this, Gholdengo outspeeds key threats such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Flutter Mane.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs make Gholdengo much more difficult to wall, with foes such as Dondozo getting 2HKOed.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Gholdengo mirror matches are common enough that maximizing Speed is usually a wise idea.
  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 212 SpA / 28 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: This bulkier spread for Choice Specs sets allows Gholdengo to survive an unboosted Shadow Ball from opposing Gholdengo, while outspeeding Timid Magnezone and Jolly Tyranitar.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo a terror against slower teams, especially with its good bulk, unpredictable coverage, and diverse Tera Types.

  • Substitute: Substitute lets Gholdengo avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure and ease prediction in general.

  • Psyshock: Psyshock lets Gholdengo break through Chansey and Clodsire more easily.

  • Focus Blast: Despite its reliability issues, Focus Blast lets Gholdengo defeat Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Gholdengo gets the jump on dangerous Earthquake users such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, Iron Treads, and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is unlikely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

  • Water: With this Tera type, Volcarona and Skeledirge are far less likely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

  • Normal: While it's a much worse defensive typing, Tera Normal does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types like Mimikyu, Flutter Mane, and Dragapult, at the cost of being weak to Mach Punch.

Items

  • Leftovers: This is the most reliable option for keeping Gholdengo healthy and pairs especially well with Substitute.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak prevents Salt Cure from chipping down Gholdengo, making it far easier for it to run Recover against Garganacl.

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon ruins Breloom's chances of winning the lead war against Gholdengo and makes Hippowdon easy setup bait.

  • Focus Sash: Despite Gholdengo's good bulk, Focus Sash is useful for giving it new opportunities to sweep.

EV Spreads

  • 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Timid: Maximizing Speed is key to at least speedtie with opposing Gholdengo, and outspeeding several threats close to this Speed tier, such as Dragonite.

  • 100 HP / 4 Def / 212 SpA / 28 SpD / 164 Spe with Modest: For sets with Recover, this bulkier spread can make sense, allowing Gholdengo to survive Shadow Ball from Gholdengo that lack an offensive item, and outpacing Timid Magnezone and Jolly Tyranitar.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
• While Gholdengo's defensive stats aren't remarkable, it's fantastic typing and immunity to status moves like Taunt make it a great defensive Pokemon.

  • Thunder Wave This makes switching into this Gholdengo very difficult, as it can punish its speedier offensive checks like Roaring Moon and Meowscarada.

  • Hex versus Shadow Ball: Hex gives this Gholdengo a good offensive kick against paralyzed foes, but Shadow Ball is worth considering for its consistency.

  • Make It Rain versus Focus Blast: Make It Rain is Gholdengo's most consistent way of dealing damage to Garganacl, but this set's defensive nature makes it difficult to win the one-on-one. Focus Blast isn't nearly as reliable, but it's Gholdengo's best shot at making it past Kingambit.

  • EV Spread:The given EVs outspeed paralyzed Dragapult, while maximizing physical bulk.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Avoiding Earthquake against foes like Garchomp makes Tera Flying extremely useful for Gholdengo; this also gives it protection against Fissure from the likes of Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Normal: Tera Normal is not incredible defensively, but it does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Mimikyu.

  • Fairy: Tera Fairy gives Gholdengo a much better matchup against Dark-type attackers like Roaring Moon, Brute Bonnet, and Meowscarada.

Items

  • Rocky Helmet: Rocky Helmet takes advantage of Gholdengo's excellent typing against physical moves, making it a good way to punish contact moves such as Outrage from Garchomp.

  • Covert Cloak: This is Gholdengo's best shot of outstalling Garganacl, since it grants an immunty to Salt Cure's effect.

  • Weakness Policy While this might seem strange on a defensive Pokemon, Weakness Policy lets Gholdengo beat opposing Gholdengo as long as they lack Choice Specs.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Gholdengo's good bulk and unpredictable Tera types make it a great user of Assault Vest.

  • Dazzling Gleam: This punishes Dark-type revenge killers such as Hydreigon and Meowscarada when combined with Tera.

  • Thunderbolt: Thunderbolt is Gholdengo's best shot at muscling past Dondozo and also deals good damage to Corviknight and Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Focus Blast: The only chance of getting past Kingambit is the inaccurate Focus Blast.

Tera Types

  • Flying: A Flying-type makes Gholdengo much more difficult to revenge kill with common Earthquake users such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting is Gholdengo's best chance of breaking past Kingambit.

  • Water: With Assault Vest, Gholdengo can tank most Fire-type attacks against it and deal good damage to Volcarona and Iron Moth. Watch out for their Grass-type attacks, though.

  • Normal: With a Normal Tera type, Gholdengo can defeat several faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult, Mimikyu, and Flutter Mane, at the cost of a worse defensive typing and losing to Breloom.

vgc2023.overview:
• Gholdengo is one of Series 1's most threatening special attackers, with a base 133 Special Attack stat and exclusive access to Make It Rain.

  • Good as Gold gives Gholdengo immunities to some of the metagame's most disruptive support moves, including Amoonguss's Spore and Grimmsnarl's Parting Shot.

  • Gholdengo is lacking in Speed, making Tailwind users such as Murkrow, Hydreigon, and Talonflame great partners. Murkrow, in particular, is a great partner thanks to Haze undoing Special Attack drops from Make It Rain.

  • Gholdengo often struggles against faster, hard-hitting Pokemon such as Garchomp and Hydreigon, making partners such as Sylveon valuable.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description:
• Make It Rain and Shadow Ball let Gholdengo take out a wide array of common Pokemon such as Armarouge, Annihilape and Sylveon.

  • Dazzling Gleam allows Gholdengo to fight back against the likes of Hydreigon.

  • Thunderbolt threatens to OHKO the likes of Gyarados and Palafin when equipped with Choice Specs. Trick is a good alternative option to lock Pokemon into undesirable moves, such as Indeedee-F into Trick Room.

  • Choice Specs makes Gholdengo one of the most threatening special attackers in the entire metagame. Choice Scarf lets Gholdengo outspeed Meowscarada, Garchomp, and Dragapult with a Timid nature, which it would otherwise need additional speed control to beat.

  • Steel is Gholdengo's preferred Tera type, boosting the damage output of Make It Rain even further and letting it OHKO Garchomp with ease.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot allows Gholdengo to secure OHKOs on just about everything weak to it, notably OHKOing specially defensive Amoonguss when Choice Specs would fail to.

  • Life Orb is the primary item used by Nasty Plot Gholdengo, boosting its damage at the cost of recoil. Metal Coat is a recoil-free way of boosting Gholdengo's primary move, Make It Rain. Air Balloon is an option to remove Gholdengo's Ground weakness, helping it match up better into the likes of Garchomp and RestTalk Dondozo.

  • Steel is Gholdengo's preferred Tera type, boosting Make It Rain's damage and removing crucial weaknesses to Dark-types. Tera Flying is an alternative that removes Gholdengo's Ground weakness without using an item, making it a great partner for Earthquake Garchomp.

sets.name: Defensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Gholdengo's incredible typing, great stats, and setup potential make it a potent wincon with plenty of defensive utility. With Fur Coat-boosted bulk or the immunity granted by Earth Eater or Well-Baked Body, Gholdengo can switch into foes like Aerilate Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Clodsire and can set up with Nasty Plot to wallbreak. Earth Eater and Well-Baked Body may also surprise the opponent, allowing Gholdengo to set up in key situations and gain a winning advantage. Alternatively, a set with Hex + Thunder Wave + Substitute lets Gholdengo make the most of advantageous situations and avoid having to switch out as often. To dually punish switches and remain healthy, Gholdengo should be paired with teammates that can set entry hazards and provide Defog support, like Ting-Lu and Ice Scales Corviknight, respectively. For immediate power, wallbreakers like Sheer Force Dragapult and Iron Valiant and Choice Band Baxcalibur and Great Tusk are excellent partners. Dragapult is a notably good partner, as it shares the same checks with Gholdengo, forming a core that can overload most special walls.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Choice item Gholdengo uses its excellent typing and stats to frustrate offensive teams and Trick to cripple its defensive checks. Choice Scarf outspeeds key threats like Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and +1 Dragonite and neutral natured Baxcalibur, while Choice Specs puts more pressure on defensive teams. Regenerator allows Gholdengo to function as an offensive pivot and repeatedly check foes like Baxcalibur, while Good as Gold deters Defog attempts from Corviknight. Trick cripples most walls—such as Corviknight— by giving them a Choice Scarf or Choice Specs, making them much less effective at doing their jobs. Nasty Plot is a great option after using Trick, while Recover fits on the Good as Gold and Earth Eater variants. Gholdengo finds itself at home on balance and offense teams that can utilize its many helpful traits, such as preventing Defog and crippling specially defensive walls. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu pair well with Gholdengo, and other special attackers like Iron Bundle and Dragapult capitalize on Gholdengo taking out the opposing walls.

sets.name: Bulky Wall
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Wo-Chien to survive a spread Heat Wave from Beads of Ruin-boosted Choice Specs Chi-Yu, then invests the remaining EVs into Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band amplifies Chien-Pao's offensive potential, which, in tandem with its fantastic Speed and coverage, allows it to effectively clean weakened teams and break apart common defensive cores. Icicle Crash is Chien-Pao's most powerful physical Ice-type attack and its status as a non-contact move means Chien-Pao can launch it without fear of debilitating effects like those from Rocky Helmet and Flame Body. Its chance to flinch can also help Chien-Pao break down walls, like Corviknight, in a pinch. Ice Spinner, while marginally weaker, may be preferred due to its perfect accuracy. Crunch is another powerful STAB option that conveniently pairs well with Icicle Crash, as it is able to hit common Ice-resistant Pokemon such as Dondozo and Gholdengo. Ice Shard lets Chien-Pao revenge kill sweepers like Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant; Sucker Punch is more powerful, but it can leave Chien-Pao vulnerable to status spreaders like Rotom-W and Hex Dragapult and to sweepers that can take advantage of Chien-Pao if it is Choice-locked into it. Sacred Sword hits Pokemon like Kingambit and Garganacl supereffectively. Tera Dark removes Chien-Pao's Stealth Rock weakness while bolstering the power of its Crunch, notably allowing it to 2HKO walls like Corviknight and Toxapex. Alternatively, Tera Ice boosts the power of Chien-Pao's Ice Shard, making it even harder to check offensively. An Adamant nature grants Chien-Pao enough power to 2HKO physically defensive Dondozo with Crunch after Terastallization, though Jolly prevents it from being outsped by threats like Roaring Moon and Cinderace.

Chien-Pao's typing leaves it vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, especially Stealth Rock, which will greatly limit the number of times it can switch in and launch attacks. For this reason, hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight are great partners for it; they also can cover several of Chien-Pao's checks, such as Scizor and Kingambit. Hazards greatly aid Chien-Pao's ability to clean teams late-game, so hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Garchomp and the aforementioned Great Tusk make for great teammates. Defensive teammates like Corviknight and Dondozo can support Chien-Pao by handling Pokemon that offensively check it, such as Scizor. Pivots like Rotom-, Cinderace, and Dragapult, make for solid teammates, as they give Chien-Pao the ability to prey on their common switch-ins like Amoonguss and Clodsire.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
By virtue of its high Speed and Attack, excellent offensive STAB combination, and unique ability Sword of Ruin, Chien-Pao is one of the tier's defining wallbreakers and late-game cleaners. Icicle Crash is preferred over Ice Spinner as it avoids Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin chip and boasts higher power and a chance to flinch. However, Ice Spinner can also be used as a guaranteed safe option if your team cannot afford missing. Sacred Sword offers good coverage that hits important metagame threats that resist Chien-Pao's STAB combination, such as Kingambit. Tera Dark is the preferred option to eliminate Chien-Pao's Stealth Rock weakness and power up Crunch and Sucker Punch to monstrous levels, enabling Life Orb Chien-Pao to cleanly 2HKO Toxapex. Tera Ice is an alternative that boosts Ice Shard enough to always OHKO Dragapult after Stealth Rock damage.

All-out attacking Chien-Pao is best used as a midgame wallbreaker on offensive teams that can take advantage of its high damage output and wide coverage to punch holes in the opposing defensive core. Late-game cleaners that can take advantage of Chien-Pao's wallbreaking capabilities include Iron Valiant and Dragon Dance Dragonite. Chien-Pao can struggle with bulky Water-types such as Dondozo, Azumarill, and physically defensive Quaquaval. Rotom-Wash is a good partner that can switch into these Water-types and either gain momentum with Volt Switch or cripple them with Will-O-Wisp. If running Life Orb over Heavy-Duty Boots, entry hazard control from Great Tusk or Hatterene is greatly appreciated. Great Tusk and Hatterene can also use their great physical bulk and quadruple resistance, respectively, to switch into Fighting-type attacks aimed at Chien-Pao.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
• Ice Spinner is an alternative to Icicle Crash because of its better accuracy, but it is slightly weaker, cannot flinch, and is a contact move.
  • Ice Shard hits Miraidon and Koraidon for super effective damage, 2HKOing the former, and 2HKOes Flutter Mane reliably. Sucker Punch may be considered over Ice Shard, as it does more damage to Iron Bundle and can KO Flutter Mane, but it misses out on revenge killing Koraidon and is often prediction-reliant.
  • Sacred Sword allows Chien-Pao to OHKO Chi-Yu, Kingambit, and opposing Chien-Pao, which otherwise resist its STAB moves.
  • Chien-Pao can use Tera Dark to make Crunch stronger and 2HKO Corviknight and Toxapex if it gets lucky with a Defense drop. Chien-Pao can also use Tera Ice in order to 2HKO Corviknight more reliably and boost Ice Shard damage—notably against Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Koraidon. Lastly, Tera Electric Chien-Pao with Tera Blast can easily break through bulky checks like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Dondozo.
  • Chien-Pao fits best with other strong wallbreakers that benefit from the removal of defensive walls. These include Koraidon, Miraidon, Iron Bundle, and offensive Great Tusk.
  • Defensive partners like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Skeledirge are mandatory to handle fast and strong threats like Koraidon and Miraidon, as Chien-Pao cannot OHKO them if they are at full health. Additionally, Great Tusk and Ting-Lu can set up entry hazards, which is crucial for getting chip on defensive walls.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Icicle Crash 2HKOes Corviknight and avoids Rocky Helmet, while Ice Spinner is more accurate and has the bonus of removing Electric Terrain.
  • Sacred Sword hits checks such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Another option is to run a double priority combination with Ice Shard and Sucker Punch. Sucker Punch hits very crucial Pokemon that Ice Shard can't, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fire Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle.
  • An Adamant nature allows Chien-Pao to achieve ridiculous feats such as revenge killing Flutter Mane from 90% HP with Ice Shard. A Jolly nature lets Chien-Pao Speed tie with Koraidon, Miraidon, opposing Jolly Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane, giving Chien-Pao the freedom to click its strongest moves less reluctantly.
  • Tera Dark allows Chien-Pao to 2HKO the entire tier while letting it still switch into weaker moves such as Shadow Ball. Tera Ice gives Chien-Pao the ability to OHKO Flutter Mane with Ice Shard, making it a terrific late-game cleaner.
  • Choice Band Chien-Pao is a wallbreaker that is best suited for bulky offense structures that love its revenge killing and wallbreaking capabilities.
  • Pokemon like Iron Treads, Hatterene, and Koraidon, which can provide entry hazard control or pivoting, are excellent teammates for Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance makes Chien-Pao immensely threatening, letting it break through bulky foes such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, and Corviknight.
  • Ice Spinner is a more reliable option thanks to its perfect accuracy, but Icicle Crash's power and flinch chance greatly help out against all foes that can take a hit from Chien-Pao, such as Corviknight and Great Tusk.
  • Ice Shard is a reliable priority attack mainly used to better deal with Miraidon and Koraidon.
  • Sucker Punch can be used as a stronger but prediction-reliant alternative that OHKOes Flutter Mane without a boost and OHKOes the likes of Iron Bundle and Miraidon after a boost. It also provides a favorable roll to OHKO Koraidon if it has Terastallized into the Fire typing.
  • Tera Dark boosts Crunch, allowing Chien-Pao to more reliably beat physically defensive Corviknight and Toxapex. Tera Dark Chien-Pao holding Life Orb can OHKO both Pokemon after a Swords Dance boost.
  • Tera Ice can be used instead to boost Chien Pao's Ice-type attacks. This also makes Ice Shard a better revenge killing option.
  • Sacred Sword can be used to hit foes that resist Chien-Pao's STAB moves, like Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao.
  • Life Orb is the primary item choice because it gives Chien-Pao a lot of power while allowing it to run a Jolly nature and not lose out on potential OHKOs.
  • Heavy-Duty Boots sacrifices a lot of power but gives Chien-Pao the ability to ignore entry hazards, allowing it to come in and potentially set up multiple times throughout a game.
  • Black Glasses in conjunction with an Adamant nature can be used as an alternative to Life Orb to not have recoil while still being able to OHKO the likes of Corviknight and Toxapex after obtaining a Swords Dance boost and using Tera Dark.
  • This set can be used as both an early-game wallbreaker and a late-game sweeper thanks to Chien-Pao's strong STAB attacks and priority moves.
  • Chien-Pao has very little defensive utility, so having a defensive core for it to fall back on is recommended for balance teams. On offensive teams, it can afford to run Focus Sash to take at least one hit from foes that would usually threaten it out.
  • Great Tusk is Chien-Pao's best teammate, as Great Tusk can handle one of Chien-Pao's hardest checks in Koraidon and provide Rapid Spin support. Rapid Spin also helps keep Focus Sash intact.

sets.name: Choice Band (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its high Speed and decent STAB coverage that hits common physically defensive walls like Gholdengo and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster offensive threats such as Barraskewda and common Choice Scarf users; alternatively, Ice Shard is weaker but hits Roaring Moon super effectively. Sacred Sword beats Steel-types like Kingambit and bypasses Garganacl's Defense boosts. Chien-Pao's best fit is on balance teams that can provide it with safe switch-ins and take advantage of the holes it creates. Noivern and Ceruledge are recommended teammates, as both can help Chien-Pao beat the incredibly troublesome Dondozo and Toxapex. Corviknight and Iron Treads are both good teammates thanks to their ability to pivot Chien-Pao in safely, in addition to clearing Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Defensive Hazards
sets.description:
Ting-Lu is an incredible entry hazard setter for bulky offense and balance teams alike thanks to its combination of gargantuan defensive stats, good utility movepool, and an amazing defensive ability in Vessel of Ruin. It also has a great typing that lets it answer threats such as Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Moth, and Ceruledge. Whirlwind is incredibly useful for thwarting setup Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Volcarona. Ruination lets Ting-Lu deal consistent damage to bulky Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Hatterene. Tera Poison lets Ting-Lu act as an answer to Iron Valiant while giving it an immunity to poison damage from Clodsire’s Toxic and letting it absorb Toxic Spikes from the likes of Glimmora and Iron Moth. Meanwhile, Tera Fairy is a generally solid defensive typing, letting it more reliably check Pokemon such as Dragapult and Great Tusk. Maximum Special Defense, in tandem with Ting-Lu's ability, makes it a more consistent check to special attackers such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Volcarona.

Ting-Lu’s premier defensive profile makes it most proficient on bulky offense and balance teams that can supply enough offensive momentum to make up for Ting-Lu’s relative passivity. Pokemon that can supplement offensive prowess to make up for Ting-Lu's passivity such as Chien-Pao, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit make for excellent partners, as they can assist against threats like opposing Iron Valiant, Dondozo, and Great Tusk. Without Ruination, Ting-Lu is utterly helpless against Corviknight, so Pokemon that can threaten it such as Gholdengo and Cinderace make for excellent partners. Bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex appreciate Ting-Lu's immunity to Electric while being quite helpful against Pokemon like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Quaquaval in return. Other defensive Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight also make for excellent partners, being helpful against Pokemon like Chien-Pao and Scizor while appreciating Ting-Lu’s ability to check Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Additional entry hazard setters such as Garganacl and Great Tusk allow Ting-Lu to fit Ruination into its moveset more capably, so it is less passive in the face of Ground-immune threats like Corviknight and Air Balloon Gholdengo.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu is a key Pokemon for many playstyles in SV Ubers, ranging from stall to bulky offense.
  • Whirlwind helps Ting-Lu against Substitute users like Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur and other threatening hyper offense Pokemon such as Agility + Calm Mind Miraidon.
  • Tera Steel lets Ting-Lu check Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle. Tera Ghost, on the other hand, lets Ting-Lu soft check physical attackers such as Great Tusk, Koraidon locked into Close Combat, Iron Hands, and Iron Valiant. Tera Fire is another option that lets Ting-Lu soft check and beat Chi-Yu one-on-one. Lasty, Tera Fairy is also an option to check Dragon-types and have an overall good defensive typing against Pokemon that would normally overwhelm Ting-Lu, such as Choice Specs Miraidon.
  • Ting-Lu works best as a defensive pivot on bulky offense teams, capitalizing on its massive natural bulk and ability Vessel of Ruin to set Spikes against Pokemon like Miraidon and Chi-Yu, tank big hits, and recover HP with Protect.
  • Pokemon that appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to wear down opposing Ground-types with Spikes, such as Miraidon and Koraidon, are excellent partners for it. Other defensive Pokemon such as Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Blissey relieve pressure of Ting-Lu by helping to check Miraidon; they also check Flutter Mane, and Corviknight additionally helps check Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Physically Defensive (Ground)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Entry Hazard Support (Dark)
sets.description: This is the sample set before we work on new analyses. This will be updated as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• This EV spread and nature ensures that Ting Lu always OHKOs Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum or Earthquake, and then uses the remaining EVs to maximize its special bulk.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Ting-Lu is a reliable special wall and a premier Miraidon check. Regenerator gives Ting-Lu reliable recovery without conflicting with Assault Vest. Nuzzle discourages dangerous attackers like Zacian-C and Palkia-O from switching in. U-turn allows Ting-Lu to safely bring in teammates thanks to its low Speed. Ceaseless Edge forces chip damage on foes, letting offensive teammates wallbreak more easily. Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Covert Cloak, making Ting-Lu's own utility more effective; it also punishes Imposter users attempting to gain Regenerator. Ting-Lu fits best on balance teams, which appreciate its ability to spread paralysis and safely bring in teammates thanks to its huge bulk. Dangerous wallbreakers like Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Palkia-O help maximize the effectiveness of U-turn pivoting. Ting-Lu is unable to naturally check Palkia-O and Quiver Dance Arceus-Water, so a teammate that helps shore up this weakness, such as Arceus-Grass or Hisuian Goodra, is appreciated. Tera Fairy provides an immunity to Dragon, allowing Ting-Lu to block Dragon Energy from Palkia-O and Choice Specs Miraidon; alternatively, Tera Grass provides a Water resistance, covering for Palkia-O's Water Spout and coverage from Miraidon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and Noivern, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Dragonite and Earth Eater Gholdengo. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Focus Blast Gengar can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammates that also provides Defog.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Gengar, Iron Moth and Gholdengo. Throat Chop lets it beat all Boomburst users and Ground-immune Gholdengo. Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce its weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu is an outstanding wall, utilizing its immense bulk, Vessel of Ruin, and useful defensive typing to check threats such as Dragapult, Espathra, and Tapu Koko well. With access to both Stealth Rock and Spikes, Ting-Lu is a flexible entry hazard setter that supports its teammates well. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to pressure Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, which don't care about its Earthquake. Rest is an option for more longevity across the length of a game, but it renders Ting-Lu useless for a few turns. Whirlwind works exceptionally well with other hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Mega Diancie, as it lets Ting-Lu wear down Pokemon quickly for its teammates, as well as phazing setup sweepers such as Espathra and Dragonite easily. Water is the primary Tera type for Ting-Lu, being overall solid defensively and letting it switch into Barraskewda and Weavile easily. Ghost is also a solid Tera type, as it lets Ting-Lu check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant, as well as blocking Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk. Water-types such as Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Floatzel easily force Ting-Lu out, making Water-resistant teammates such as Ferrothorn, Slowbro, and Dragonite great partners. Due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to Fighting-types like Mega Medicham, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta, Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge work really well alongside it. Gholdengo in particular forms a potent defensive core with Ting-Lu, preventing its entry hazards from being Defogged. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant all pair amazingly with Ting-Lu's hazard support. Lastly, due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to hazard chip damage, entry hazard removers like Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk are invaluable partners.

sets.name: Feesh (Offensive Wallbreaker)
sets.description:
• Overheat hits extremely hard and can 2HKO even the bulkiest of Pokemon. Fire Blast and Flamethrower can be used to KO foes without Chi-Yu suffering a Special Attack drop, with Flamethrower having perfect accuracy.
  • The only reason to run Timid over Modest is to outspeed Jolly Great Tusk, Jolly Annihilape, and fast Iron Treads with Special Defense investment.
  • Tera Fire allows Chi-Yu to turn 2HKOs to OHKOs, for example OHKOing opposing Chi-Yu with Overheat. Tera Fire also lets it 2HKO any prominent special wall, including Toxapex, Blissey, and Ting-Lu, OHKOing them with sun.
  • Choice Specs Chi-Yu is a wallbreaker, suited best for offensive teams. Koraidon is an excellent teammate because it sets sun and pivots Chi-Yu in with U-turn. Koraidon and Chi-Yu also threaten each other's checks, like Koraidon threatening Blissey and Garganacl and Chi-Yu threatening Skeledirge and Dondozo.
  • Helpful teammates are those that can get Chi-Yu in safely and force out its few checks. Corviknight and Koraidon are noteworthy examples, pivoting into special walls such as Ting-Lu. Lures such as Heavy Slam Koraidon and Great Tusk, which beat Dachsbun, and Psyshock Flutter Mane, which beats Toxapex and Blissey, are also appreciated teammates.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
• Fire Blast is Chi-Yu's strongest STAB move without any stat drops. Psychic is an alternative that 2HKOes common switch-ins such as Dachsbun and Toxapex. Overheat facilitates revenge killing, hitting even Pokemon that resist it such as Koraidon hard, and is a better midground play.
  • Memento serves as a way to facilitate sweepers like Swords Dance + Flame Charge Koraidon that Chi-Yu is usually paired with.
  • Tera Fire powers up Flamethrower and Overheat to nuclear levels, turning 2HKOs against Pokemon such as Koraidon into OHKOs. Tera Dark nullifies Chi-Yu's Stealth Rock weakness while making Dark Pulse 2HKO Dachsbun and Toxapex. Tera Grass should only be used with Tera Blast; it gives Chi-Yu nice resistances to Ground and Water and allows Chi-Yu to OHKO Great Tusk and 2HKO Ting-Lu after Spikes damage.
  • Choice Scarf Chi-Yu is a revenge killer best suited for offensive teams.
  • Pokemon that can get Chi-Yu safely into the field, such as Koraidon, Miraidon, and Corviknight, are excellent teammates for it. Koraidon also sets up sun, further boosting Chi-Yu's Fire-type attacks.
  • Ting-Lu and Glimmora can set entry hazards to guarantee some 2HKOs, such as against opposing Ting-Lu.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot Chi-Yu can threaten to KO foes it couldn't otherwise, such as Ting-Lu and Blissey. Overheat hits extremely hard and threatens to OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Flamethrower is valuable for its perfect accuracy.
  • A Modest nature alongside Life Orb lets Chi-Yu OHKO Ting-Lu at +2. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used instead to give Chi-Yu more opportunities to switch in, but the loss of power is notable.
  • Chi-Yu fits best on offensive teams with Pokemon such as Cyclizar and Grimmsnarl that can facilitate its setup. Sticky Web support from Masquerain is also useful, as it lets Chi-Yu outrun Pokemon like Koraidon and Miraidon and KO them at +2.
  • Chi-Yu's best partner is Koraidon, since it sets up sun, can safely bring Chi-Yu into play with U-turn, and threatens Blissey. Other good partners are special attackers that benefit from special walls being neutered by Chi-Yu, such as Miraidon, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo. Great Tusk is also greatly appreciated, as it can remove Stealth Rock and threatens Blissey and Ting-Lu for Chi-Yu. Chi-Yu can deal with Corviknight and Dondozo in return.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO Ice Scales Corviknight and physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Dragapult and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Ice Scales Corviknight, Garganacl, and Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Iron Hands make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Booster Energy
sets.description:
Dragon Dance Roaring Moon is one of the tier's most threatening late-game setup sweepers due to its high offensive stats, strong coverage moves, and decent bulk. Earthquake is a strong, consistent coverage option that hits Kingambit, Garganacl, Iron Hands, and Clodsire super effectively. Roost, on the other hand, gives Roaring Moon access to reliable recovery, which gives it more setup opportunities throughout the game even if its Booster Energy is already used up. Acrobatics has fantastic coverage, as it hits Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Breloom super effectively and should always be run alongside Tera Flying to maximize its power. Iron Head is a viable alternative to Acrobatics and should always be run alongside Tera Steel, as it deals with Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Hatterene simultaneously. Tera Flying removes all of Roaring Moon's baseline weaknesses bar Ice, gives it a resistance to Fighting- and Bug-type attacks, a Ground immunity, and a STAB boost to Acrobatics. Tera Steel, though more niche, allows Roaring Moon to resist Hatterene's Dazzling Gleam, Chien-Pao's Ice-type attacks, Scizor's Bullet Punch, and Tera Normal Dragonite's Extreme Speed. A Jolly nature is typically run to outspeed Booster Energy Iron Valiant after a Dragon Dance, but Adamant is a decent alternative, particularly on teams that allow Roaring Moon to obtain more than one Dragon Dance boost. After a Dragon Dance, Adamant Roaring Moon can more easily OHKO defensive variants of Gholdengo and Great Tusk.

Dragon Dance Roaring Moon best functions on offensive teams, pairing well with setup sweepers that can wear down each other's checks. Espathra appreciates Roaring Moon's ability to pressure opposing Steel-types, Iron Valiant can opt out of running Psyshock, since Roaring Moon breaks past Clodsire for it, and Breloom can more effectively utilize its STAB moves and Spore once Roaring Moon eliminates Gholdengo. Dondozo and Tera Fairy Skeledirge are major threats to Roaring Moon due to their ability to ignore its boosts with Unaware, while strong priority users like Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Breloom can revenge kill Roaring Moon thanks to its low Defense. Ting-Lu can force Roaring Moon out with Whirlwind, and Choice Band Iron Hands survives a boosted Earthquake from full health and can OHKO Roaring Moon with Close Combat. Espathra can muscle past Dondozo, Skeledirge, and Iron Hands thanks to Stored Power, while Iron Valiant offers more immediate damage against the aforementioned threats and Ting-Lu due to its excellent mixed coverage. Offensive Great Tusk and Technician Breloom can help wear down Ting-Lu with their super effective STAB moves, and Breloom's Technician-boosted Bullet Seed can also break past Dondozo. Grimmsnarl's ability to set up dual screens allows Roaring Moon to set up multiple Dragon Dances and survive attacks from Chien-Pao and Dragonite. Orthworm is a niche option that sets entry hazards and provides a slow Shed Tail to get Roaring Moon in safely behind a Substitute, allowing for much easier setup opportunities against opposing status users like Rotom-W and protecting it from priority moves from Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Breloom.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

This exciting new Paradox Pokemon is likely to have an impact on Battle Stadium Singles Series 2! While we wait for the metagame to settle, here are some sample sets to get you started. For more information on Series 2, check out the resource thread.

If you feel that this analysis is missing important information, feel free to leave feedback here.

sets.description: This set is currently undergoing copyediting. If you would like to see the analysis in its current state, check it out here.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description: This set is currently undergoing copyediting. If you would like to see the analysis in its current state, check it out here.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Roaring Moon's Dragon / Dark typing and high special bulk enable it to switch into Gholdengo, Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and other special attackers, setting it apart from other offensive pivots like Greninja and Iron Moth. Earthquake forces out Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Moth and Kingambit. Iron Head and Stone Edge target Florges and Noivern, respectively. Roaring Moon fits best on teams in need of a pivot with both longevity and a Speed tier that exceeds the likes of Chien-Pao and Barraskewda. Roaring Moon struggles to break past physically defensive foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands, so it appreciates having strong special attackers such as Armarouge and Gengar as teammates. Steel-types like Corviknight and physical walls like Great Tusk are great for patching up Roaring Moon's defensive blind spots.

sets.name: Mixed
sets.description:
High attacking stats and a wide array of coverage moves make Iron Valiant a devastating mixed attacker that can 2HKO common defensive walls physically and specially; Moonblast and Thunderbolt threaten physically defensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Corviknight, and Dondozo, while Close Combat and Psyshock deal with specially defensive foes like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Its Quark Drive-boosted Speed from Booster Energy turns it into a potent late-game cleaner, letting it outspeed would-be revenge killers like Dragapult, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo, which is further enforced by its unique typing that resists Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao. However, it can also be used to revenge kill boosted threats like Baxcalibur and Dragonite in a pinch, especially since Iron Valiant can take on the latter's +1 Tera Normal Extreme Speed from full health. Tera Fairy boosts Iron Valiant's Moonblast while still retaining its defensive profile to take on Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Tera Electric amplifies Thunderbolt's damage, notably allowing it to 2HKO would-be checks like Toxapex, specially defensive Dondozo and Tera Water Garganacl, and offensive Gholdengo after Stealth Rock, as well as preventing Iron Valiant from being revenge killed by Scizor's Bullet Punch.

Mixed Iron Valiant is commonly seen on offense and bulky offense teams. Due to the lack of a damage boosting item or setup move, it can still fall short of threatening bulky Pokemon like Amoonguss, and without Shadow Ball or Knock Off, Skeledirge and defensive Gholdengo as well; thus, Pokemon that can deal with them such as Great Tusk, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit make good teammates. Particularly, the aforementioned Pokemon can overwhelm a shared check in Corviknight and are generally effective as early-game wallbreakers that can open up Iron Valiant to clean up late-game easily. Entry hazards from teammates like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Glimmora can chip down foes like Garganacl, Amoonguss, and Tera Grass Dondozo. A sturdy defensive backbone with the likes of Corviknight and Ting-Lu can help check offensive threats that threaten Iron Valiant out, such as a boosted Roaring Moon, opposing Iron Valiant, and Gholdengo. Pivots like Dragapult, Scizor, and Rotom-W can compensate for Iron Valiant's lack of bulk by bringing it in safely on foes like Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Blissey, respectively; the latter can also cripple Amoonguss with either Trick or Will-O-Wisp. Gholdengo is a great partner, as it reliably prevents the much-needed entry hazards from being removed by Rapid Spin and Defog, threatens Skeledirge and Tera Fairy Garganacl, and appreciates Iron Valiant dealing with foes like Corviknight and Dark-types like Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon in return.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Iron Valiant utilizes a deadly combination of offensive power, coverage, and Speed to function as one of the best sweepers in OU. After a Quark Drive boost, Iron Valiant outspeeds and OHKOes a plethora of premier offensive threats in the tier, such as Chien-Pao, Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Roaring Moon. Thunderbolt allows Iron Valiant to damage Corviknight and bulky Water-types like Dondozo, Azumarill, Toxapex, and Tera Water Garganacl, while Psyshock scores a 2HKO on any Clodsire looking to stop Iron Valiant's sweep. With Calm Mind, Iron Valiant can switch roles from an endgame sweeper to a powerful wallbreaker. After one Calm Mind, Moonblast 2HKOes defensive Garganacl, and +1 Tera Electric Thunderbolt 2HKOes specially defensive Slowking and OHKOes Corviknight. Tera Fairy powers up Moonblast, which can now 2HKO Garganacl and Hatterene. Tera Electric boosts the power of Thunderbolt, which secures important 2HKOs on specially defensive Dodonzo, Corviknight, and Toxapex, lets Iron Valiant survive Scizor's Bullet Punch, and grants Iron Valiant an immunity to paralysis from Hatterene's Nuzzle.

Iron Valiant relies heavily on its super-effective coverage moves for damage output. As a result, it struggles to make progress against Pokemon like Volcarona, Skeledirge, and Gholdengo. Thus, teammates like Clodsire and Ting-Lu are good defensive partners for Iron Valiant, with the added benefit of being able to set up entry hazards. Iron Moth has strong offensive synergy with Iron Valiant, being able to threaten Amoonguss, Iron Treads, and Tera Fairy Garganacl, while also being able to chip down special walls like Clodsire. On offense teams, Iron Valiant complements powerful wallbreakers like Chien-Pao, Nasty Plot Gholdengo, and Kingambit, since they can overwhelm defensive cores and open up the path for Iron Valiant to sweep. Finally, Iron Valiant is highly reliant on Booster Energy to sweep, as it cannot normally outspeed common revenge-killers like Chien-Pao, Dragapult, Cinderace, and Meowscarada. Therefore, it is important to time when to switch in to Iron Valiant to ensure defensive counters like Skeledirge and Volcarona are either removed or heavily damaged so it can sweep or break through the opposing team effectively. Along these lines, it is important to conserve Iron Valiant's health, since it can survive key priority moves such as Extreme Speed from Tera Normal Dragonite after a Dragon Dance and Ice Shard from Choice Band Chien-Pao. Therefore, Pokemon that can remove entry hazards, such as Great Tusk and Iron Treads, are great teammates for Iron Valiant.
